content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												MUST NOT BUY for following major reasons:1. EXTREMELY BUGGY since the launch of game. Unacceptable issues has been brought up with almost every month's patch which makes us nearly think they're here to make the game worse: how the car viewing angle turned 90deg with chase cam when your car's overlapping another opponent's car in no collision race (solved), stuttering issues for high-end PCs (NOT SOLVED AFTER A YEAR), nitrous not working for online races with manual without at least 1 car reset since Wild Run, NOT SOLVED WHAT THE... , and this March patch what has just turned up? ATI and Nvidea graphics users might not even able to start the game and game crash straight away.2. RUBBISH car physics. Even by arcade standards the physics are pure trolls, EVEN AFTER WILD RUN. For god sake Ubisoft your game engine is based on Atari's Test Drive Unlimited 2. How the hell  could you possibly make it so much worse than that game what the FU*K? O_O TDU2 at least has friendly controls while still retains bit of realism, if by no means much ... but you Ubi, bikes that can go to complete stop from 350km/h/220MPH in less than 2 seconds plus hit the wall at almost 90deg and still no crash, catch-up mechanics and INSANE AMOUNT of slipstream that can allow a car to override top speed by 70km/h and TOTALLY ruins online competition, collision physics that allows your car to "skid" past traffic even when u hit them head on, race cars that can go 420km/h with those huge wings+corner 50% faster than in reality ... it's honestly disgusting in its own way. I rather have something even more detached from reality (e.g. Burnout, Ridge Racer) than experiencing your half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥efforts trying to go for poor extents of realism.2.5. Extra steering rate for non-DirectInput controllers and steering wheels. Ehm yes ... if u uses either 1 of them you have an unfair advantage of being able to steer the front wheels so much at any speeds and the car can still response to such even at likes of 300km/h because of bullsh*t overpowered tire physics.3. Poor online structure. In simplest terms, The Crew uses some of the worst multiplayer connection programming which results in players in the same lobby who're not host to have latency. This often ends up with the host "off-sync" from his actual positions causing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ stuff including both palyers slipstreaming each other on their own screens and the 3th place host player in a close finish ended up 1st in result screen. "Summit" tracks also lacking checkpoints real badly, forcing top players to go for insane shortcuts for majority of them.If you really want to buy a racing game from Ubisoft, honestly, I rather hope you may consider trying out "POD GOLD" which is from the f**k-graphics 90s and you can download from GOG site for just $5.99 featuring compatibility for Windows 7 or above. Yes it's full arcade physics and no graphics quality to talk about, but it's got beautifully designed track layout + AI difficulty that can put you to smile for losing so badly just like those games in arcade centres. I can safely bet for most POD is even better than this piece of typical modern crap which other gaming companies seemed to have learnt from EA's NFS somehow just to steal money from kids. Topping with Ubi's Assassin's incident, I swear I would never buy Ubi's racing game for the 3rd time.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Absolute piece of rubbish. From the unwanted Wild Run "upgrade" that is one big advertisement for the Wild Run DLC, to the inexplicable graphical and physics bugs, and the rubberbanding AI, stay away from this game. It doesn't matter if you are a fan of racing games or massive open worlds, this game is not worth your time. Trust me, I've played 100+ hours and I just had the final straw. While playing a long-running faction mission (> 1 hr long) the road disappeared and left me unable to steer, accelerate or brake. I had to abort the mission. The usual fix of bringing up the map doesn't work because you can't bring up the map during missions. If you are a fan of games that have a well-designed difficulty progression then this game is not for you, either. Some missions are overly easy and others that are ranked as easy are next to impossible. Likewise, some hard-ranked missions are way too easy. It's as if random goals were set for each mission and the difficulty rankings were randomly set as well. That said, if you like games where you have to grind to progress, then this game is for you. Not only do you have to grind for upgrades, but just playing the game is a grind. In my experience the most fun thing to do in the game is to free drive with your friends, and not the game itself.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Pros- Decent wheel support for an "arcade driving" title. At least with a Logitech G27.- OK car physics and handling. Hardcore "petroheads" are probably going to laugh at this but from my experience, car handling is fun AND challenging.- Huge and very diverse environment. Driving game with huge environment are not exactly common so...- Nice graphics during sunrise and sunset: Very impressive lightning.Cons- Extremely poor support of TrackIR. Cannot even look behind with it while you can with the mouse!- Glitches: All over the place. Floating cars, "cars inside" the road, floating rocks, slight but constant stuttering when loading assets. Heck, during a cut-scene, my car literally went through a prop in the scene!- Intense network rubber banding/teleportation of other players cars.- Washed out, ugly lightning effect during storm and raining... Nights are also very dark. Lightning is not consistent: Range from superb sunrise/sunset to WTF moments at night and during cloudy weather. - The game use some sort of "instancing" where players are not necessarily going to encounter each other, even when exactly at the same spot on the map.- Lots of DLC exclusive content and "buyable with real currency" cars. Not a fan of the latest.- Of course, UPlay, which totally sucks. Add another layer of unneeded complexity to the whole experience. So, if I could, I would give a "maybe" rating. But I can't so, I have to rate it negatively.If you like sand box, non-hardcore driving game, you might find it interesting. Exploring the map is a blast... but expect glitches. Get it during a sale at 50%-80% rebate.

												When im being chased by police in this game it makes me rage more than call of duty because you can be 2 miles away and somehow their crown victoria can catch up to you within 5 seconds.Pros :- Great map, it's really awesome;- Graphics are good;- Cockpit view, the interiors are well designed;- Simcade driving is fun;- Many specs ( Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid and Circuit ).Cons:- Lack of cars, only 47 fullstock cars (if I'm not wrong.);- Exterior car custimization is just poor:- 200 rims ? And you get like the same rim with 3/5 different colors. - The bumpers, some of them the only thing that changes is the headlights.- Stickers, pre-made stickers that you can't even change the color of them;- The MMO , ... when you launch the game you can see like 100 people on the same server as you, but while you are on free-roam you can see up to 8 people. That's like driving offline, with an option to PVP that will take you to a lobby with 4~8 people to race against.- Cockpit view:- When PVPing if there's no collison , the other player will just pass by your car and you won't be able to see nothing in from of you, only a black shade of your oponent.- In cockpit view your mirrors don't work;- AI , the AI is just impossible, if you are being chased by the police it's really hard to escape. You can go 400 km/h with a Circuit SLS on an Highway that a Ford Crown Victoria will chase you down. - Some of the game physics are just out of this world:- You get rammed by another player or a AI car your car just fly's away, you try to ram a cop you get stucked.- You hit a fence or a pile of garbage on the sidewalk you lose like 10/20 km/h;- PVPing, sometimes you need to wait 5 minutes to join a lobby to get rammed mostly.- In PVP the lobby leader (the player with most wins) is the one who dictates wich track you are going to play and the settings, with or without traffic/collision, instead of being choosen by a vote among the lobby players.(...)And there's the Crew Credits, that for me it's neutral, in my point of view they are there to help people that lack of time to "farm" money to buy a car that they like, or parts of it, for people that buy the game to play 3/5hours a week.Because you can easily make money doing pvp races (15~18k bucks each race and with perks the most expensive car is like 708k), you can buy all the cars and parts without having to buy the CC's.Should you buy the game?Yes/No.- Yes, if you are into this type of games, but buy it heavly discounted.- No, if you buying it full price, because for the price that they are asking for it they should give players way more stuff and not this. To me this was the most expensive "early-acess" that I've ever bought.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												I am in two minds about this game. The gameplay itself is quite enjoyable, it's an arcadey racer much like Driver San Francisco. But there are far too many flaws for me to recommend this. 1) The grind! If you want a decent car you better be prepared to either grind tedious missions over and over or buy some in game credit. Most missions net you 2k, but top of the range cars come in at 700k not including the tuning which some will set you back 500k. That's a lot of grinding for little reward.2) The story is abysmal, I didn't care at all about what was going on or who these people were. Which would be ok if it wasn't for;3) The missions. The missions in this game is the same repetitive few types with different locations/cars. It will either be a race (by far the best), an escape from the cops mission, a checkpoint time trial or a Smugglers Run esque cargo smash. That is as deep as they get and you will soon get bored. 4) Little reward. I don't really consider this a spoiler and I think perspective buyers should be aware. There is no reward for completing the story. No car. No paint job and just the same diddly amount of cash as the rest of the missions. 5) Always online and Uplay. Not really an issue for me but understand this is important for people with limited internet connectionsThat being said there are some positive points to this game. The map is huge and full of landmarks, the Wild Run add on creates a bit more variety, and if you manage to get a crew cruising round the U.S.A can be fun. I have played this with a Logitech Driving Force GT and it will work ok, but the arcade controls are far more suited to a controller, both controller types are supported well with mappable button configs.All in all I can't really recommend this game, especially not at full price, but it may be worth a punt on sale if you are looking for an easy on the eye arcade racing sandbox. It is what it is, and is easilly worth getting on the cheap for the map and crew antics alone.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												What The Crew gets right is its stylised and scaled-down version of the entire continental USA. Cities are shrunken caricatures, but the truly vast sweeping tracts of land between them means traversing it really does capture the spirit of a cross-country, city-to-city road trip better than any driving game before it. Plenty of racing games curate a bunch of different backdrops into their track selections, from urban street races in major American metropolitan centres to icy blasts across snow-swept mountains, flat-out sprints across the baking desert, or muddy expeditions through giant Sequoia forests. The Crew admirably does all this in a single game world you can drive across in one lengthy session.This girth has come at a cost, though. It’s a world that looks fine whipping by you at speed, but it favours sheer size over the kind of granular detail we now expect in modern open world racers. Cities are smattered with recognisable landmarks but don’t really seem built to stand up to stationary scrutiny. Combined with low-detailed NPC cars (complete with entirely black, opaque glass), some forgettable effects (splashing water is especially dire), no weather, and the fact that the models of the 40-or-so cars are in a league below those of contemporaries like Forza Horizon 2 or Driveclub, The Crew struggles to shake the look of a game several years older than it actually is.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												The Crew is basically what people wanted after black box got fired. It has a big map that can take minutes to hours to explore with a lot of variety when it comes to terrain and climate. There is hidden wrecks that you can find across the map with different specs such as Street Dirt raid perf and curcuit. Most of the wrecks are hot rod based and they have a lot of features when it comes to customization. There is a lot of customization in the game such as bumpers spoilers skirts vinyls rims paint but there is something that has been bugging me and that is that some cars doesn't have that much customization options if not anything at all. Like the maserati gran turismo s you basically have no options here except for changing the OFFICIAL rims or the OFFICIAL colours. You can't customize the gran turismo s. And in curcuit spec there isn't that much options either you basically get a big body kit but with no options to change it. Just like raid spec you only get that 1 body kit. Also there is a lot of cars / specs from the trailer missing in the game and cars that I would love to be in the game. there is only 2 import tuners in the game and that is the 370z and the skyline R34. Where is the Evo's or the RX7 / RX8's Supra's GT86's ETC? The 2012 Dodge charger has mitsubishi evo parts but it isn't the same. The story is very short and very difficult trough the end most likely just to make the gameplay longer. I'm not sure if this game was rushed or they just lost their creativity but if you bought this game just for the story you will be very dissapointed. It feels like the full game didn't include the full story and it just ended too fast.The physics are very weird in this game. Sometimes you will get random cutscenes where your car flips and crashes which is skip-able but still can get annoying at times. ESPECIALLY during missions or pvp races.After exploring almost every part of the  crew bought and customized almost every car in the game and found almost all of the wrecks there isn't that much to do anymore. Sure it is fun to do road trips at times but it can get very repetetive.Overall: Awesome game for cruising and customization but it lacks some features such as fenders specs and cars. Especially japanese cars which highly dissapointed me because there is only 2 japanese cars in the game :S Huge map with a lot of different areas to explore and cruise with your friends.8/10

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												I will write a quick, straight on review for those who are wonder how the game is.This come from 33 hours of gameplay, story done, top 90th in pvp some days ago.There are things that bothers me about the game:-Customization part is that there aren't really many hoods, bumpers and stuff to chose from they mostly have little details changing between them, and they are usually tied to a spec, so this mean, no Skyline stock hood on a Perfomance spec Skyline! Bumpers and the rest are usually repetitive, not to mention the vynils You can't change their colours.-MMO feeling, this is the misleading part. In your world (your session) you will only be able to see 8 players on the whole US (at least for now) Yes, 8 this is not your typical MMORPG where you see hundred of people. So keep that in mind if you were thinking about it- Lack of JDM cars: Only three. Ain't gonna describe this much, just three, the rest is almost entire muscle cars with some european exceptions._______________________________________________________________________Story is entertaining, not much to add into this part, characters are fine, not precisely boring, but nothing out of this world :]Cops are incredibly fast, think about artificial difficulty, just like that, a crown vic can catch your LaFerrari full throttle, something like Most Wanted, but way more aggresive, if you like challenges, then i guess you will like it, but sometimes, it's a bit unfair, and they don't share the same physics as your car (you can't slam them offroad, they are like anchors)One important thing, people tend to whine about the boat handling like GTA IV. It gets A LOT better on the mid-end game, the starter cars are the problem, and the fact it's a MMO, you NEED to level up to get better handling, speed, and so on, and it is highly recommend to play without assists.Cars are all the same performance wise when you upgrade their parts to max, this means that if you are not a 16 y/o bugatti fan, your favorite $50k grand car will be able to compete to an Agera R and not remain obsolete in the the early levels!Cruising on the states is an amazing feeling, at least that's what i felt since im kind of NA enthusiast in the future. Just keep in mind that this game is way better with friends, so you better get someone in with you. It will make the exploration feeling incredible, and there are plenty of stuff to do. From Skills, to PvP, and Co-Op missions (races up to 2,5h and maybe more!)To finish this quick review, my final words:I think the game is on sale somewhere (christmas season maybe?)Is the game worth it's full price? If you ask me, i do not regret it. Is it fun even in solo? It is, yeah pretty much. Will it be supported for a long time? It's a game that doesn't have a direct competitor on PC, so think about it :]See you in the States if you decide to give it a try! Claxon me up if you see a Gun Metal Gray R34 rocketing on the roads ;]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Prelude and Tl;Dr    I beta-tested The Crew back when it was first announced for beta, and at that point I believed there was true potential to the game. The story, while cliche, wasn't terrible like some other racing games of late. A large and open world full of sights, and iconic cars. BUT, as release came, I am left wondering what if anything they did, Servers are worse than anything I have experienced, Only 25ish cars, physics that beg belief, and a map upon further inspection leaves you scratching your head in disbelief at the laziness of the devs. So no I do not recommend this game, it has some good moments in the free driving, yet you still have that nagging presence of all the issues and poor quality.The map    One of the positive things of the Crew is the map, it is big, ~100km across and has some detail in it. Honestly you can spend hours driving and still be discovering new places, which makes cruising down a road and being able to say, "what is that" and go find out the best part of the Crew. However the map has massive issues, a mesh that makes even games from the 90's shudder to look at. Case in point, just driving over a desert, which is pretty flat, you will occasionally ramp off and spin out, all due to such a low polygon count that the ground is jagged and often impractical. It is bad enough I will not use my FFB wheel in the crew due to the jolts it will give the mechanisms in the wheel. The textures are barely passable for a game of 2014, and often are quite lack luster. And the bounding boxes on object and the road often do not match the objects and can cause frustrating moments as you spin off or stop dead due to a fence or some invisible outcrop in a building. MAP (6/10).The Cars   there are only ~25 of them, and there isn't much different between them when they are in the respective specs. Also the specs available to put on a car are limited, some cars can have all, while others can only have one spec installed. AWD cars feel like FWD cars, RWD cars feel like drift cars. The Physics are at their best are abysmal and often cause a moment of frustration followed by eruption of laughter as your car is catapulted from hitting a foot high rock into the sky. There is also a general disregard to grip as cars tend to slide more than turn. CARS(5/10) PHYSICS (3/10)The Specs   The specs offer the true differences between cars as some will be off-road "capable" (nothing is prepared for the horrible polygon density) and others fast on road. There can be some fun to be had racing the different specs, but the physics issue often steals most of the fun, when the other issues are not. The Missions/Skill Challenges   Fun, for the first couple, then a long drag to the end, often making you look at the next mission and groan. The race type is straight forward, the checkpoint missions often are the only ones that are enjoyable, the takedown missions are messed up and often don't recognize the hits, and the smash the crates are just plain idiotic. As for the skill challenges... Jumps are awesome, speeds makes you hate the traffic, scrambles frustrate, race lines are meh, presicion frustrates, slaloms make you hate traffic, seeing the pattern? MISSIONs(4/10)The AI   ♥♥♥♥♥♥ than PayDay 2, nuf said... AI(1/10)Servers   Yeah, what servers? Can't stay connected for more than an hour and often dumps you out of the race at the end when in COOP giving you no rewards for the hour long race you just completed. Often can't see friends who are right in front of me. SERVER(0/10)Pay2Win...Summary (4/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Me Giving a Bad Rep for this game doen´s mean that I wouldn´t recommend it all, but the thing is: The game has too much going against it to really recommend it. The game throws you right into the Actionand it gives you some nice cars to play with right from the get go and within the first few hours of gameplay you get to drive cars from 4 of the 5 Spec sets so you can get a glimpse of what lies ahead. And you can do all that either on your own or in Co-Op with a Crew of either some random people or with your friends. The game tries to tell a story about revenge and stuff, but it is so narrow with unintresting characters that it makes Fast and Furious look like The Godfather in comparsion. However I do like the variety in gameplay, you get to drive some races, escape the cops every once in a while, take down a target, destroy some boxes for reasons or just try to get to the finish line within a timelimit. All that both on- and off-road. I also like the huge map, you need roughly 90 minutes to get from New York City to Los Angeles, and just to make sure that you don´t get bored during your road trips you get tons of little Skill Challenges all over the Place, these range from jumps to Race Line challenges and you can win parts to updgrade your car and money in these challenges. The Map itself is basicly a compressed Hollywood Version of the entire USA (not Including Alaska and Hawaii) without all that boring stuff. It´s the first time in an Open World Racing game that I don´t feel that the game world is limited too much.You can visit tons of famous Towns and Landmarks, the map also Includes some, honestly bad, recreations of real life racetracks, you get everything from the time Square to the Hollywood Hills, you can drive up the Pikes Peak or reach insane Speeds on the Boneville Salt Flats, you can Visit Mount Rushmoore, the Swamps in the Southern Regions, take a road trip along the Route 66. You get the point. The Car Handling takes a while to get used to, but once you figured out how to drift around corners it gets much easier because you would have to slow down way too much to drive around corners the regular way.However here is why I don´t recommend it, and uPlay isn´t any of the reasons, I don´t mind it too much. The game requires you to be online all the time, if the servers goes offline for whatever reason or you loose the connection the game throws you out of whatever you are doing, even if that means that loose your 3 Hour Progress into an almost 4 Hour long race. However there is no real reason that the game has to be connected to a server at any point because you can do everything on your own. Also the game is NOT an MMO in the classical sense, while in Free Drive you randomly drop In and Out off Online Lobbys, players inside a Lobby can Invite others into their Crew and play Story-, Faction- and PVP-Events together. A Crew can have up to 4 Players and all 4 will Drop In and Out off the Sessions together. While it works, it almost feels like a gimmick to me.I have a feeling that the car Levels and Perks don´t mean anything, at least when there is AI Involved. The game has some of the worst rubberbanding AI I encountered in over 20 Years of playing Racing games, even with cars close to Level 900 you can´t really drive away from the Low Level AI in the earliest Missions th game has to offer. When Playing PvP the Car Levely do Matter, however a goog driver can still beat a car that is 200+ Levels above him when the other driver isn´t that experienced. The whole concept is untransparent, you never get a feeling that all the carparts you collect even do anything.Also it throws you the Option for Microtransactions in your Face every time you are anywhere where you can buy stuff within the game. You can get everything without ever using them, but I get a strong feeling that you don´t earn money fast enough in the game so they can sell more micro Transactions.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												[Closed BETA Review]Finally a good competitor against NFS. I'm a huge fan of NFS series myself. I have all PC versions of them since 1994. And i can tell, in my opinion, that this game made the perfect balance that EA didn't do in 20 years: A vast and consistent open world (also real places), mix the simulation and arcade style, and have cars for other purposes (Dirt and Raid).Looking forward to see the final version.[Final Version Review]Although i maintain most of my previous statements, after playing almost 100 hours, here's my considerations:-They managed to make a worst history telling than EA. Too much clichè, weak story. -No invisible walls! NICE!-The car selection is modest, but they say there will be more cars, so ok...-They could improve the physiscs.-The graphic is amazing. I give you that.-There are races with 2h duration on the game that award a good money. But UPlay is very unstable and after a few frustrations i quit trying to do that races, because if you're disconnected for some reason (most of the case is their fault), you lose the race and all your effort.-The police has some tactics, do PIT maneuvers, has helicopters, but i think there could be more challenge. Also spike strips, rhino units and faster backups.-The car tuning and custom parts are good. Could be more options though.-The rubberband AI levels in this game is too damn high!-Although they say it's a car MMO, you can only see 7 players max. Also, i rarely found someone to play with.-And most important. There's micro transactions in the game. They're not vital, though. I bought several times and the transaction got bugged. Took weeks to receive the proper credits.[Wild Run Review]Now they f... upSo they managed to make you pay for the base game and buy credits to decently progress in the game. What a shame...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Prelude and Tl;Dr    I beta-tested The Crew back when it was first announced for beta, and at that point I believed there was true potential to the game. The story, while cliche, wasn't terrible like some other racing games of late. A large and open world full of sights, and iconic cars. BUT, as release came, I am left wondering what if anything they did, Servers are worse than anything I have experienced, Only 25ish cars, physics that beg belief, and a map upon further inspection leaves you scratching your head in disbelief at the laziness of the devs. So no I do not recommend this game, it has some good moments in the free driving, yet you still have that nagging presence of all the issues and poor quality.The map    One of the positive things of the Crew is the map, it is big, ~100km across and has some detail in it. Honestly you can spend hours driving and still be discovering new places, which makes cruising down a road and being able to say, "what is that" and go find out the best part of the Crew. However the map has massive issues, a mesh that makes even games from the 90's shudder to look at. Case in point, just driving over a desert, which is pretty flat, you will occasionally ramp off and spin out, all due to such a low polygon count that the ground is jagged and often impractical. It is bad enough I will not use my FFB wheel in the crew due to the jolts it will give the mechanisms in the wheel. The textures are barely passable for a game of 2014, and often are quite lack luster. And the bounding boxes on object and the road often do not match the objects and can cause frustrating moments as you spin off or stop dead due to a fence or some invisible outcrop in a building. MAP (6/10).The Cars   there are only ~25 of them, and there isn't much different between them when they are in the respective specs. Also the specs available to put on a car are limited, some cars can have all, while others can only have one spec installed. AWD cars feel like FWD cars, RWD cars feel like drift cars. The Physics are at their best are abysmal and often cause a moment of frustration followed by eruption of laughter as your car is catapulted from hitting a foot high rock into the sky. There is also a general disregard to grip as cars tend to slide more than turn. CARS(5/10) PHYSICS (3/10)The Specs   The specs offer the true differences between cars as some will be off-road "capable" (nothing is prepared for the horrible polygon density) and others fast on road. There can be some fun to be had racing the different specs, but the physics issue often steals most of the fun, when the other issues are not. The Missions/Skill Challenges   Fun, for the first couple, then a long drag to the end, often making you look at the next mission and groan. The race type is straight forward, the checkpoint missions often are the only ones that are enjoyable, the takedown missions are messed up and often don't recognize the hits, and the smash the crates are just plain idiotic. As for the skill challenges... Jumps are awesome, speeds makes you hate the traffic, scrambles frustrate, race lines are meh, presicion frustrates, slaloms make you hate traffic, seeing the pattern? MISSIONs(4/10)The AI   ♥♥♥♥♥♥ than PayDay 2, nuf said... AI(1/10)Servers   Yeah, what servers? Can't stay connected for more than an hour and often dumps you out of the race at the end when in COOP giving you no rewards for the hour long race you just completed. Often can't see friends who are right in front of me. SERVER(0/10)Pay2Win...Summary (4/10)

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Me Giving a Bad Rep for this game doen´s mean that I wouldn´t recommend it all, but the thing is: The game has too much going against it to really recommend it. The game throws you right into the Actionand it gives you some nice cars to play with right from the get go and within the first few hours of gameplay you get to drive cars from 4 of the 5 Spec sets so you can get a glimpse of what lies ahead. And you can do all that either on your own or in Co-Op with a Crew of either some random people or with your friends. The game tries to tell a story about revenge and stuff, but it is so narrow with unintresting characters that it makes Fast and Furious look like The Godfather in comparsion. However I do like the variety in gameplay, you get to drive some races, escape the cops every once in a while, take down a target, destroy some boxes for reasons or just try to get to the finish line within a timelimit. All that both on- and off-road. I also like the huge map, you need roughly 90 minutes to get from New York City to Los Angeles, and just to make sure that you don´t get bored during your road trips you get tons of little Skill Challenges all over the Place, these range from jumps to Race Line challenges and you can win parts to updgrade your car and money in these challenges. The Map itself is basicly a compressed Hollywood Version of the entire USA (not Including Alaska and Hawaii) without all that boring stuff. It´s the first time in an Open World Racing game that I don´t feel that the game world is limited too much.You can visit tons of famous Towns and Landmarks, the map also Includes some, honestly bad, recreations of real life racetracks, you get everything from the time Square to the Hollywood Hills, you can drive up the Pikes Peak or reach insane Speeds on the Boneville Salt Flats, you can Visit Mount Rushmoore, the Swamps in the Southern Regions, take a road trip along the Route 66. You get the point. The Car Handling takes a while to get used to, but once you figured out how to drift around corners it gets much easier because you would have to slow down way too much to drive around corners the regular way.However here is why I don´t recommend it, and uPlay isn´t any of the reasons, I don´t mind it too much. The game requires you to be online all the time, if the servers goes offline for whatever reason or you loose the connection the game throws you out of whatever you are doing, even if that means that loose your 3 Hour Progress into an almost 4 Hour long race. However there is no real reason that the game has to be connected to a server at any point because you can do everything on your own. Also the game is NOT an MMO in the classical sense, while in Free Drive you randomly drop In and Out off Online Lobbys, players inside a Lobby can Invite others into their Crew and play Story-, Faction- and PVP-Events together. A Crew can have up to 4 Players and all 4 will Drop In and Out off the Sessions together. While it works, it almost feels like a gimmick to me.I have a feeling that the car Levels and Perks don´t mean anything, at least when there is AI Involved. The game has some of the worst rubberbanding AI I encountered in over 20 Years of playing Racing games, even with cars close to Level 900 you can´t really drive away from the Low Level AI in the earliest Missions th game has to offer. When Playing PvP the Car Levely do Matter, however a goog driver can still beat a car that is 200+ Levels above him when the other driver isn´t that experienced. The whole concept is untransparent, you never get a feeling that all the carparts you collect even do anything.Also it throws you the Option for Microtransactions in your Face every time you are anywhere where you can buy stuff within the game. You can get everything without ever using them, but I get a strong feeling that you don´t earn money fast enough in the game so they can sell more micro Transactions.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												T-Boned a car, whilst going 323km/h down a road, launching it vertically 20 meters in the air and 30 meters down the road.Respawned from the crash, car is still in the air10/10 would Crash againEdited Proper Review as of 11/12/2014.Warning 'The Crew' is not a Simulation racing game, it is an ARCADE Racer.if you are looking for a decently fun racing game to play. 'The Crew' is a considerable choice for this.There are few issues however with the game such as.The Cops and pursuers are OP, especially so in the earlier levels of the game. Later on as you become a higher level, they do become less OP, but are still OP but not to the same level as they were when you first begun the game. The cops aren't that hard if you know how to use the Specs of cars properly. There is a large number of people complaining about this issue, most likely a majority of these people, have no clue how to drive each of the specs of cars correctly. (Don't be one of these people, learn the specs correctly).Warning, this isn't a Racing Simulator don't be like the Racing Elitest like those that are prowling the Forums.'The Crew' does have some other teething issues, such as occasional lag during co-op missions, Lack of connectivity to other players and difficulty connecting to friend when attempting to join each others crew's (I'm from a country that the national average internet speed is 10 mbps, and the lag isn't even that horrendous for me) .  These issues, are considered to be Teething issues, as the game hasn't even ben out for 2 full weeks yet, the people ♥♥♥♥♥ing about all of these issues aren't taking this into consideration, and these people aren't taking in to consideration that almost no games at launch are 100% Glitch Free / 100% Bug Free / Balance correctly / have no lag and connection between players is working correctly.This being said 'The Crew' is actually quite an enjoyable game to play, as summarised, there are a balancing issues, connectivity issues, etc If you are thinking of purchasing this game, honestly if you don't mind not playing with some friends or dealing with occasional OP AI pursurer/cops, then you should definitely purchase this game.If any of these issues do effect you eg occassional Lag, connectivity issues with friends or you get really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at the cops for some reason, as if you have a deep seeded issue with all forms of Law Enforcement. Then i would wait a bit for these issues to be fixed by ubisoft.7/10 (would be 8.5 or 9, if the connectivity issues and balancing issues were corrected :D )

												This game statisfy what a good online racer game is supposed to be. most players that did not liked this game plays realistic racers such as Forza or Grand Turismo. as for the other portion of players they will really be pleased whit this game since it have a NFS: Most Wanted and Test Drive Unlimited taste, witch is pretty good for a release from ubisoft, even tho, its true that some bugs remains, as other big games had before when they got out, but we know they will get those bugs fixed, so thats not a big suprise or a big deal about it and it can happen, at least those bugs are noting major, (unless you have a crappy internet connection)For the Interested, here is the Pros/Mids/Cons of the game.PROS++ Racing coop (up to 4 player max per mission or pvp game)+ Very detailed environment (Working NPC's, a lot of Wilflife and alot of map details)+ Better graphics than Test Drive Unlimited 2+ Detailed leaderboards and statistics for everything+ Good car handling and controls (with a few exceptions since its a NFS styled game) + Polices Forces that can chases you almost evrywhere. (give challenge somtimes)+ Open world where you can drive wherever you want (Even discover some easter eggs in the world)+ Good transition between game cinématics and gamplay (So you fell like you gived control of it after mission movies.)+ Posibility to send your friend do faction missions for you. (so you can save time instead of doing a 2h mission for a bit more of easy game money)+ 50 Cars for first release batch (Witch is not bad for a game that features quite detailed car interiors)+ Offers car customisation such as pre-fab vynils/stickers, Rims, Spoilers and some chasis mods. ( Alot more visual customisation to offer compared to TDU2)+ Day and Night Cycle SystemMIDS~~ Servers are down for maintenance sometimes. (yes it can happen, its an online game)~ Uplay Launcher (at least i can be used / merged whit steam tho)~ Storymode is a bit short. (but is still entertaining to watch)~ Missing Mirrors Animations for Cockpit view in some Cars. (they already working on it already for next patch )~ Weather conditions changes only when you go the mountains where there is snow (they might could use a bit rain but its not that bad)~ Can have unblanced AI (depending if you and your crew have to high level gap)CONS-- No offline mode (you need a internet connection to play this game)- No possibility to add your own Music (but you can customise your playlist atleast)- MicrotransactionsSo as so far for the rest for the game and the gamplay itself, the pleasure of free roaming those cars with friends is pretty Neat, if your one of thos players who dislike this game, just go back to driveclub or what so ever other racing sim game you were playing, otherwise if your looking for car tunning, driving everywhere from road to montains, and like fast paced races for the fun of playing it, this game i what you are looking for !All together i would say, "The Crew" is a cool game to play for cruising around with Friends or even to play alone i would say, sure the game have some bugs and have a litle lack on MMO since its more concentrated on the NFS genre gamplay but is worth the price when we know they will comme up whit more !(10 thumbs up)Continue the good work Ubi we know that you can do it and update this until perfaction as other titles did before !!(Afterall They made Driver San Fransico a great fun game so why not the crew !)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												(AFTER 20+ HOURS EDIT) This game did not turn out the way it felt early on. You feel like a total Bad@$$ through the first bit, then you keep playing with the same car, just little upgrades to it, then you keep playing, and keep playing, and keep on... Eventually, you beat the final race, and you've still only got the first car you bought (or in my case with pre-order, a Mclaren). My in-game wallet after the whole story line, was just enough to buy a mid-range car. Anything in the modern era that's considered a "SuperCar" was still too much for me, but hey! You can always buy credits on their system to get enough, only a mere $XX.xx+ to unlock this car! Unfortunatly, you can see below from my review, I was hoping this would feel like Test Drive Unlimited, which I have 200+ hours in (on xbox) but it just did not meet up. In test drive, after the story you feel rich, buying mansions, yachts, bugatti veyrons, etc. In this, you'd be lucky to end up with a mid-range prius. Unfortunatly, The 5 other people ever online do not seem to be driving anything in the super car range either, so there's nobody to ask how they made their money. Oh well, another dust collector.(Old Review) What can I say. I'm a sucker for open world racing games.This game feels like TDU3, the game I've always dreamed of. I put many hours on TDU2 (Xbox) and always looked for a game that would compare. Need for speeds customization features have just gone off the radar since they're underground series, which is the only thing that made that series fun. The Crew, although just played in beta, felt like a perfect combination of the two games. A decent amount of cars (Will be 50-60 from what I've heard) lots of customization, and lots of land to drive. It took me about 2.5 hours to drive from New York to San Francisco. I made a few stops in Vegas, Grand Canyon, And other landmarks of course. I can't get enough of this game, and can't wait for the full version to be released.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												***Disclamier***I would NOT recommend this game for anyone looking for a driver simulator like Forza or any game similar. This game plays like the classic NFS titles. Arcady and smooth. The damage model is not gonna be like Next Car Game:Wreckfest, itll be like that of NFS. So if your hoping for that be prepared to be disappointed.OkayPro:-Large map and no loading times! (like itll take you about 90mins to drive across the map)-Plenty of challenges aside from the story to improve your driving-PvP!-Lots of cars to pick from-Lots of Customization-No game breaking bugs-Game is optimized/no driver issuesCons:-From what i see you have to earn car parts, you cant buy them. This is what ive seen.-There is an option for micro transactions =/-You must use Uplay-Sometimes players wont populate the map and takes sometime.-I was hoping to be able to create my own decals for my car, everything is predetermined.Overall I would recommend this game. Good arcade driver! Also even though Ubisoft has the publishing on this product, it is Ivory Tower who created the game, which explains a pretty bugless launch compared to previous titles from Ubisoft.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												I just spent two and a half hours driving from Chicago to LA along Route 66, obeying speed limits and stopping every now and then to admire the beautiful scenery. Most of the locations in the game have this authentic kind of feeling to them. While the level of detail doesn't match that of GTA V, it's still high enough to make you keep on playing and exploring the vast open map.Apart from that, well, it's a decent multiplayer racing game. The amount of cars to select from isn't exactly whopping, and there is no photo mode to capture the scenery I mentioned earlier. The AI traffic can suddenly take to the skies and Boeing 747's spin around wildly while airborne. But overall, it's an enjoyable experience if you can ignore the servers shutting down every two hours. Hopefully the developers will manage to get rid of that soon.  Simply put, if you liked TDU, NFS:MW, Burnout Paradise, MC:LA and the likes, you will most likely enjoy The Crew as well. You might want to wait for a few weeks before getting it, though.8/10PS: I wouldn't mind an offline mode.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I used to consider this to be a great game and would have recommended it, but while I don't regret buying it, I wouldn't say it's worth anything more 60% off retail price, meaning most sales will be meaningless, it's still not worth the buy.As a US cruiser, it's a decent game, though you will suffer from the flat textures on buildings and apauling physics, still, other parts of the game are nice, it's definitely amazing driving through the wild plains, deserts (especially death valley) and the fields of green rolling hills. Cities are just really boring to drive through though.Chances are that after finishing the story, you won't have explored everywhere (and some places are really golden as previously mentioned) and there will be things like faction missions available, little trials on the road like driving fast or jumping far and you can even replay individual missions.But what happens when you get bored of the monotony or driving around? You can buy more cars to do more driving around, though this does require vast amounts of grinding that may or probably not seem worth it. You will then decide to buy the crew credits instead through microtransactions, which... don't bother! So naturally, the best thing to do would be to replay the story. That's what I like doing, especially driving games, but naaaah!! You can't replay the story. You can only do the individual missions. Parts of what made the story a cohesive story are no longer there. What's better is that Ubisoft know their player-base would like such a feature to go through the story again in the linear fashion it was originally in but still refuse to implement it.Bottom line is that I wouldn't recommend this game because it does lose replayability. It simply becomes a cruiser after a while. Racing against other people isn't even really a big part of it. It's very rare that I get even a gimpse of racing other people. Instead, you'll have some random driver drive alongside you until they get bored.

Driving the cars in this game with my Logitech Driving Force GT feels so relaxing after a stressful day.Got the Complete Edition on sale. I didn't buy this game initially since there were mixed reviews about this game. But now I feel bad for not buying this game earlier. This game is so underrated. This game is so much fun while cruising with friends. There were days I played this game sacrificing my sleep. Everyday, after coming home from work I used to spend time in gaming. I didn't expect the cars to have realistic driving physics because I just wanted to drive and have fun. Isn't that gaming is all about? I love the weather cycle, different terrains, meeting different people who drive along with you, competing with other players online,etc. I don't have anything to hate about this game. And I'm definitely gonna buy the Calling All Units DLC.

												Its not terrible. The game  itself is fun, but it is kind of a waste in a way also. Given the size of the map and extremely small amount of visible players allowed, it feels pretty much dead. It claims it is a living game, but in reality it isn't. There is nothing innovative about this game. Basically it is a prettied up version of NFSW with less visible players and a better map. Other players in the game seem to keep to themselves, have yet to find a pvp match or co-op in time played and I queue for it fairly often. I bought this game on sale and still feel kind of ripped off. I'd give it a thumbs up if it was in the under 10 section, but its not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												I cannot recommend this game to anyone. It's grossly plagued by A.I glitches, fantasy car data, a huge lack of selection and server instability. If you are a car person and actually know anything about cars, this game will frustrate you. The A.I in this game defies all laws of physics from letting a 1960's mustang out turn and out run a pagani huayra to magically and without warning throwing your car about 100 feet in the air on a straight stretch of empty road.None of the cars in this game perform even remotely close to their real life counterpart. Frustrating to car people, otherwise a minor detail most won't care too much about.This game has a heavy bias for American cars, and an overall fleeting selection of cars. Essentially there are only one or two cars worth getting for each category. This is not Gran Turismo or Forza, do not expect that.But worst of all is server instability. You are guaranteed, regardless of how superb your internet connection may be, to be disconnected on a regular basis during or even worse right after crossing the finish line. None of your progress will be saved and you'll be forced to do the race again. This is particularly frustrating during the long endurance races.The story is a complete joke, but that's not why we play these games. It is however worth mentioning that my most anticipated racing style 'circuit' is actually identical to 'performance' racing (racing through traffic on public roads) but done with circuit category cars. Only ONE race in the entire game is actually done on a race track. Despite there being several race tracks in this game, you only ever race in one with your circuit car. The remainder of circuit races are done on public roads identical to any performance race.There is NO end game content. You only ever need one car per category of racing (and many categories can be achieved with one car). So unless you have a burning desire to collect every car in the game, once the story line is complete there is no reason to continue playing. Even the bonus cars you can get through finding parts throughout the country are all performance wise, terrible cars (with the sole exception of the buggy).The ONLY redeeming factor for this game is the environment. It's absolutely stunning and a joy to explore in. When a race comes together and works it can be an enjoyable experience but I cannot recommend this game to anyone because it feels like a beta, that costs you 60 bucks.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												I've been playing The Crew base game for a while since November and I only came upon it after the late-2015 patch which upgraded the graphics and physics of some cars.I love the game, yes.The Crew is simply the best driving-in-an-open-world game available on the PC, and the highlight of it is the virtual continental America with a great variety of enviroments for driving enjoyment. The cities in this game does not have a living-breathing feel, yet they act as huge playgrounds for driving the somewhat limited line-up of cars available in the game. I think Manhattan in The Crew is no smaller than GTA IV's Liberty City. The mountains and seasides in The Crew, however, are truly great places to get yourself lost in. The great open Americana-esque environment with ever-changing weather and time of day indeed provide a immersive experience which is hard to be found in any other driving games.This is a game made for virtual world explorers who happen to sit in a car seat and don't really care about too much about serious racing. The Crew's missions and racing can have result varying from exciting(compete in the snowy mountain road around Salt Lake City) to very boring(it totally miss the opportunity to make NYC as racing tracks interestingly). But the overall 'road trip' feel in this game is awesome.Then there's this always-online problem. I love the idea of 'Never Driving Alone' but the real experience is having the very common 'lost connection to server' headache... An offline 'Enjoy Driving Alone' will be appreciated, really.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												If you’re someone who enjoys a racing game with beautiful, customisable cars, but gets bored of the usual race-to-the-finish-line gameplay, The Crew is what you’re looking for.At first glance, the game seems to lack in its graphics quality, but as you speed through the streets of the United States in over forty main missions, prove yourself in eight different skill types, and swap from all-terrain trucks to exotic sports cars to suit the occasion, you’ll quickly forget about that. And while the game is designed for multiplayer, most of it is just as suitable for single player.Underlying the beautiful gameplay of The Crew is a deep story following Alex Taylor as he joins the FBI to take vengeance on the leader of a nation-wide underground motor club named the 5-10s. As he travels from state to state, he recruits friends to help him rise through the ranks of the criminal organisation.The multiplayer game features five distinct car specifications; you’ll find yourself teaming up with friends and other online players to weave through the streets of New York in your Street car, drifting on dirt roads in your Dirt spec, racing down Route 66 in your Performance supercar, taking down rivals in your Raid truck, and hugging the racing line of designated tracks in your exotic Circuit spec.However, you’ll find that the game has its fair share of drawbacks. The first few missions, which are completed in your Street car, are quite short and hence less rewarding. Once you move onto Performance, the races will become much lengthier, allowing the pace to ramp up to frantic speeds as you narrowly dodge traffic on windy highways.The rubber-banding is also definitely lacking; if your car is too levelled up in late-game, the other AI racers will fall behind in the first stretch, and the distance will grow as the race progresses. This isn’t an issue during multiplayer, when you can focus on beating your friend – but when you’re playing alone, it often feels like more of a cruise than a race.On top of that, don’t expect the police chases to be too challenging. While this isn’t the game’s main feature, this is one aspect that could have been implemented much better. I’ve found myself too easily losing track of the cops because they can’t keep up, and this takes away from the enjoyment of having the police hot on your heels while drifting around the block.While the game can definitely be enjoyed in single player, I would recommend grabbing a few friends and hitting the roads. If none of your friends are crazy for a racing game (or, alternatively, if you have no friends…), you can join up with whoever’s online around the world to give yourself a better challenge. Either way, The Crew is a truly enjoyable game for the story-driven gamers looking for varied gameplay.

												It's a lot of fun, but after a while it become monotonous and rather boring. Overall there is a lot to do with faction missions, skills and story missions. Leveling is quite easy, but there is an incentive to level up as there are some nice rewards. The map is very large with a lot to do in it. God help you if you're at the end of an hour long race and you lose connection.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												When it comes to open-world racing games, this is one you'll at least want to try. The story is pretty boring and as generic as it gets, and the selection of cars seems somewhat random, but let me tell you where this game shines the brightest; the open world. Ubisoft has managed to take the entire country of The United Sattes, and shrink it down and put it into a racing game. The car customization is pretty good if you are looking to make your car the way you want. The performance tuning isn't wonderful, mainly just a "this piece is a higher level than this one so it's better for your car" but that being said, at least it has actual car parts to upgrade (tires, suspension, gearbox, etc.) instead of just upgrade speed or handling. But like I said early, where this game shines is in the open-world exploration. It has dynamic and chaning environments with rain and day/night cycles, a vast variety of landscapes raning from the tropical florida keys, to the big NYC, the snowy mountains of the northern rockies, the dry deserts of the southwest, and the beautiful coast line of California. And taking a large road trip in your favorite custom car and exploring the world is one of the best things I've done in a video game before.There are plenty of side activities and challenges to do, and plenty of fantastic roads to explore and drive on. If you are looking for an open-world exploration game with car customization and racing, this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												The Crew has gone through many beneficial changes from when it was first released. The Crew is an open world arcade racer that emphasizes playing with friends and car customization. The map is an abridge vesion of the United States. Major landmarks and cities appear, but smaller, lesser known places are absent from the game. Players can drive on or off the roads, and can use different car "specs" to traverse the land easier. These specs can be visually customized to fit the player. Performance upgrades are also available. Car selection is varied but limited. DLCs are available for more cars. The driving physics are arcade-like compared to simulation-like. Note: it is an 'always online' game.Overall, it's a "meh" racing game. 6.5/10Buy on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This game gets a bad rap and maybe some of it, deserved but I got this game during the holiday sale and I love it! The map, while obviously a heavily fictionalized version of the USA but still a huge and fun map to explore. As a long time GTA player, I unlike others like the handling of the cars in the crew. My only real complaint is the known stuttering issues, none of the fixes seem to work for me but it's not that bad in my case and something experienced in other mmos that have lag or other issues. I just think it's more noticable while driving 100 mph down the road vs wandering a fantasy realm...My only other complaints have nothing to do with the game itself but I am inclouding it none the less. YES, uplay, it still sucks and is still a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ It requires a key from STEAM to activate in Uplay which isn't clear to everyone and even then uplay recognises the steam version, but also initiates a second download in it's own folder so I now have the game on my pc twice, not sure if uninstalling from uplay will affect my steam version so I am leaving it alone. It also seems to think I am loading the game from an optic drive as it always asks for a disc in D drive 4x before the game launches.The game, taking this issues aside is one of the funnest driving games I have played in some time. This game should be tried and given more consideration, IMO.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												I bought this game on sale for 15 euro and so far I've been having a lot of fun. There's a lot of diverse arcade racing content here. Street racing, circuit racing, rally, off road are all different enough from each other to make a fun racing experience.But the best part is probably the huge map itself. It's a scaled down version of the US and you can drive from one side to the other with no loading screens. The only negative parts I can think of are the crash physics and not enough people on the same server as you. If you like arcade racing games, go ahead and try it, it's pretty cheap for what it offers.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												Looking at some reviews like this guy:"I don't understand how the sale of this game isn't considered fraud. If you buy the base game, you will lose $15 and after 2 hours of playing you will be FORCED to purchase "The Run" expansion pack. You literally can't play anymore unless you spend more money. It's absolute horsesh**. Highway robbery. I payed for a racing game, and you didn't give me that." I'm not even sure why you bother writing horsecap like this.. one of my friends who has the vanilla game and not "The Run" whatever that is, I guess you mean Wild run, the expansionpack? He has no problems playing with us who has it, and is NOT forced to buy it by the game itself.You bought a game, where you can race street cars, dritcars, raidcars etc, offroad, on circuit tracks.HOW can you say this is not a racing game? you can't? thought so.. anyhooThe game is far from perfect.. But my god its fun to just drive with your friends- Bugs like getting stuck ontop of rails, getting sucked into cars.- Very grindy if you want all cars to max level.- Insane waittime if you want to play crew vs crew in pvp.- Woodpecker song if you listen to the ingame radio (Worst problem)- Laggy pvp, as its peer-to-peer connection (alot like Call of Duty)+ A good list of cars from small cars you could tip over with your left foot, to hypercars.+ Very good customization for the cars.+ Daily income (which you increase by doing faction and pvp races)+ The world is huge and open, with lots to see and insane amounts of stuff to do.+ A endless timesink for the completionists out there, doing all the challenges, getting all the cars with all their specs to max, and so on.And for those complaining about the EXPANSION-PACK not being included in the season-pass (which is a pass to get all DLCs for that coming season) Well.. boohoo :)Would I recommend it? Well... yes, it is not a GREAT game but its a damn fun one.// Peace

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												As someone who really enjoyed NFS Underground 2, this game felt very reminiscent, the story is good enough to at least keep playing through the campaign and the cars handle great as long as you put the time in to level them up. The map is awesome, it spans something like 110 kilometers across from Seattle to Miami and a lot of places in between, it's a lot of fun to cruise across the country with friends just exploring. The only downside is that this game is pretty pricy when you include Wild Run. Definitely check this game out when it goes on sale if you enjoy racing games that are more casual than Forza.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Highly recommend this game. Sure, it has its ups and downs, but i won't list all of them for you. Although I don't exactly agree with the price, and the graphics being a bit outdated, I think that this game is great for friends to play. Its multiplayer is not as expansive as i would like it to be, though i can see reasons why this is limited. Just to list off one, gameplay. Anyways, the cars are good, although i dont like the fullstock edition of the cars. Handling is bad, grip is awful, and other things make fullstock cars undesireable. But, once you get them upgraded and even get platinum parts (not that im saying bronzes and silvers are awful parts,) the cars actually become quite good. With a good storyline, and a variation of types of cars, this makes this game quite amazing in a sense. Plus, with the freeworld driving it makes it relaxing just to drive around and cruise for awhile. One of the best mechanics I'd comment on is the police. Yes, the police. I'd almost say that its a bit of annoying on the story missions to get away from them, in freeworld, it isnt that bad.  Although the helicopter's one thing that takes away the fun of running from the cops, the escaping mechanic is well designed, and i think that the range of detection is perfect. A bit fast escape for perf and circuit spec cars, especially with a running start and a straight road.Anyways, enough of me rambling. I give The Crew™ an 8/10. Well done ubisoft.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												Always remember the sheer scale of this game. It is absolutely massive, driving doesn't feel restricted in the sense of the world you are given to explore. The driving is good too, kind of arcadish, but you can really feel the weight of the cars too. The game does a great job of keeping you from feeling lonely. There are always players driving around near you, and the pvp lobbies are active. The graphical fidelity of the cars is very good, quite detailed models. The environment is lacking in comparison to other triple-A titles but once again, remember the scale of the game. There has to be some sacrifices made to allow a game of this size to run smoothly (which it does by the way, if you exclude the occasional lagger that joins into your game). Although, the environment still feels well fleshed out and with thoughtfull map design for driving. It at least gets the general shape and locations right for each place as well. Like i am from seattle, and I can tell you there is a lot left out from the city in game but I could identify it in a heartbeat.Overall, one of my favorite racing games played to date, very customizeable cars aesthetically with a large, persistent open world multiplayer racing (and dedicated pvp lobbies too). I would definitely recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												The only reason you should buy this game, and I stress this, the ONLY reason, is if you love the idea of driving around the United States of America. The map is the selling point of this game. A gigantic condensed map of the US, Driving corner to corner it a moderately quick car, enjoying the sights and the roads, will take you about 2 hours or so. The map is just so massive and diverse, and once you get out of Detroit and Chicago, it is so ridiclously pretty. I am biased as I have travelled all over the US, so I know city they are trying to show off. They have captured the essence of each city fairly well, with perhaps an exception of Detroit, New York and Chicago, which seem very dull, likely due to the lack of crime, pedestrians and traffic. Many of the other cities look and feel pretty spot on, especially approaching Las Vegas. However, this is the only positive of the game.The car selection is limited and dissapointing. They all handle horribly. To get something remotely playable, you need to greatly fine tune the handling, otherwise it is far too vague and unresponsive.The story in The Crew is so bad, it makes any Need For Speed story worthy of an Oscar in comparion.The game is a true dissapointment in every sense of the word... except for the map. Once you have the handling fine tuned to something remotely playable, and you manage to find one car of any remote interest. Once you hit the road and just drive, this game is more enjoyable than any other sandbox driving game, Forza Horizon included. Driving around the coasts, paticularly near New Orleans, Miami and over towards Texas is a sight to see. Driving through New Mexico at night or early evening/morning is unreal.

												This game apart from what is said before is an amazing car game where you can find others and crew up or go solo.Pros:1.Good Graphics2.Variety of cars and their different driving style on the road3.Fun PvP events and tracks n modes to play4.Very beautiful world to explore on freeroam and a pretty big one as well5.Dev team is actually working on bugs and glitches and fixed a lot of issuesCons:1.High speed car impacts are designed poorly resulting in some bad feedback after collisions2.From time to time there is a loading loop in pvp events3.Vinyls and tuning is simple and doesn't let for much customization4.Can be grindy at higher levels5.Auto Transmission doesn't let you reverse gear like NFS series6.The DLC of the game is not free.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												After about 23 hours as of this review I'd say I have enough time under my belt to write a review so here it goes (If there are any spelling errors or gramatical errors, forgive me I type pretty fast and make mistakes). And yes UPLAY is needed for the CREW (some say this is bad some don't care. I'm one of those that don't care)The crew I had many speculation's about because people had said that it wasn't an MMO or very open world, and that you had to drive up on hills to find these stations that reveal the map like in assassins creed. People also said the story is very short and not interesting at all. So firstly let me make my claim over these.Is the crew an MMO?   A. No it is not, you are locked into a session of 8 people and you will never see more than that. Someone may leave the game and a new one will join in your session but that's about it. For the most part you see people here and there and maybe you drive by them or pull up and rev your engine to race, but that's it. Other than the PVP events and races you're pretty much flying solo on this one.Is the crew open world?   A. YES and in a very big way. Ever since Need for Speed hot pursuit I wanted another racing game with a very open world aspect and the CREW (for me) delivers in a big way. You start out in detroit but you can drive on down to Miami and then drive to the Grand Canyon, up to Niagra Falls and down to L.A. To me, that's pretty damn awesome. Now, is The CREW a realist representation of the USA? Yes and No, Yes they have included many major cities and landmarks as well as some famous and surrounding towns but for the most part it's highways and open roads. But they have done well to add in many other key things in between such as marshes down in Miami, many farmlands in the Midwest. And a lot of the forestry seen is pretty on par with what would be in the surrounding terrain. So is it a 100% accurate rendition of the US? No, because otherwise you'd spend days to just drive down to Miami. But is it a big open world that is like the US and offers a lot of Free Driving fun? Yes, in a BIG way.Do you reveal the map with Viewpoints like in AC?    A. Kind of, you have data stations which detail monuments and skill mini games found on the roads, that's pretty much it. Where the revealing of the map comes into play is when you drive on a road or in an area it starts to reveal the map where you drove. The only other kind of "Drive and find this" is the hidden car parts for hot rod's and that's about it.Is the story bad?    A. In my opinion it's OK, it feels like Ubisoft was going for a Fast and the Furious kind of story in a sense. But the bulk of the story is cutscenes and using races to solve issues which makes the story kind of boring here and there. But I do keep guessing as to how the story will play out so it's kept my attention at least. Now I'll detail Pro's and Con's of the crewPro's-Open world-A fair selection of cars to choose from-Lots of customization for your cars-Driving and racing is fun-Driving controls are good (I use an xbox360 controller)-Many different car customization options for off road, racing, street racing, circuit racing, etc.-For a racing game it doesn't look bad, you generally focus on the roads and your car (cars look like they are a high texture though) so texture quality isn't a huge biggy, up close you can see the lower textures but like I said, you're driving and racing in 3rd person so it's not an issue.Con's-Not an MMO, an 8 player session is not an MMO, I'd prefer if anything a 32 player session or maybe 50. I think an MMO style with hundreds of people racing could become hectic.-Framrate dips in big cities with lots to load. I'm running a GTX 980 Ti and see frame rates of 20-30 FPS in larger cities, all other times I usually got around 40-50's even in forests.-Even more customization options would be good-Microtransactions to buy more money and "CREW credits." You don't have to do this and can easily earn your money by just playing but this micro transaction method in gaming really needs to stop. You can also pay $3(I think) for some other vehicles that can only be bought with your real money but they aren't anything special luckily.-No custom music options in-game, this is something I really wish they put it. No idea why they can't. It's not a huge issue because I can just run it in borderless windowed and run a playlist of my own stuff on the side but it's still a minor inconvenience.Overal I'd give the crew maybe a 7.5/10. It's fun and a really awesome open world driving game, I just wish more people could be in a session and framerate dips in larger cities weren't a thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Honest Review (Spoilers might included):This is the first time I play a game made by Ubisoft. I enjoy this game a lot (since I can explore the USA). And I don't care if the game have to launch Uplay, it's their game anyway. Let's start.It's true some (or most) of the missions usually have a same kind of objective, I don't deny it and it's kinda boring. But hey, I'm not rating the game only from the missions they provided to us. The driving style kinda nice, but not too good, it's not way too simulatoristic, but also not too arcadish. For the perfomance part, you might want to farm it a bit since it's kinda hard to get a good parts. The physics, yesss, I also notice that, the glitches and stuffs, but I found that funny to derp around. And no, the game not way too glitchy, don't worry.The playground also HUGE, they cut a few parts of USA though, but whatever, it's BIG ! The map have a lot of activities to do, mostly just the same type of skills run, like speeds, precision. Don't worry about going from place to place, they got Fast Travel (After you explore the area first of course).The AI catchup system might be the annoying part of the game, but that also keep me awake for the entire races, making the races not boring. Depend on how you see it in the end.The cars, they don't have too much of it, but still have a nice modification, even though we can't freely modify the vinyl and the size of wings, etc etc~, but it's still nice to me. You don't have to go to your garage everytime you want to change your car, just a few buttons tap and voila! You use another car!Pros:- A large playground for you to play.- You learn how to activate product on Ubisoft.- Buy this game when on Sale!- A new photo mode when freedrive!- A Sexy nerdy girl, why not!- Wild run expansion might be needed for more fun (Monster Truck! but you can't run over civ's car with it, only for stunts like flips and 360).- You can have up to 4 person (include you) in a crew.- Canadian border works!Cons:- Need to farm to get a good perfomance part and money.- AI catchup might be annoying if you can't handle it too well.- Overpriced Cars even though they look cheap.- Too bad you can't save your race in the middle of it. if you tend to lose connection, I suggest don't buy since this game required a full internet connection.- Most story missions contain same kind of objective that might make players bored.I'll add more stuff to this review later.I rate it 7.9/10Cheers!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												The Crew has made me question whether anything new can be added to the racing genre. Games like Gran Turismo and Burnout seem to have cornered the market in terms of innovation merely because they got there first and racing games are typically as bare bones as games go. The Crew attempts to add new features but falls short and instead you get another brown, typical racing game. Does this make it bad? No. Is it good? No. The Crew is simply here and yet theres something about driving across country in cars you can only dream of owning that adds a sense of awe and scale to an otherwise generic game.Essentially The Crew is the first racing MMO. The idea is superb, you and everyone playing are there, competing, racing, doing challenges and exploring the entire US mainland in real time but unfortunatly falls and fails nearly everywhere. PVP has no matchmaking and is simply you VS anyone who joins that particular lobby. So someone driving a level 1200 Aston Martin can compete against someone driving a level 300 Mini Cooper and you wont know who is driving what until the event is locked in and about to begin when everyone picks their car. Lastly is the "expansion" and I use this term loosly, called Wild Run. This adds several new Specs that largely cant be used outside of the "summit" which is the largely competitive monthly meet that you must qualify for weeks before hand by partaking in stunts or freedrive challenges. Now, I have no Idea what freechallenges are, no body ever accepts my challenge invites and I never get invited, so I simply have no idea what it even is.All in all, The Crew, like most recent Ubisoft games, comes across with vast ammounts of potential but never lives up to any of it. Its here, doing what it does. It looks pretty at least.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												The sense of speed is spot on in this game. And that, for me, is a huge factor in how well I enjoy a racing game. If I'm going 100mph I want it too look and feel like I'm going that fast. The graphics, while impressive at times, do suffer from a slightly low-fi look at times. I imagine this is because of the sheer size of the world. Your car will always be in the spotlight and will always look the best, however. So don't worry about that. I can forgive slightly muddy textures in the environment as long as my car and all of my customization looks good.
