												Lots of people are complaining about bugs, crashes, Ubisoft sucking♥♥♥♥♥and not helping the game in any way except releasing more DLC. But if you can look past all that you get a really quite fun open world driving game, where you can drive all over America. There are a fair bit of cars, nowhere near how many most people would like, but enough to keep you busy. There is the problem with that if you want the best cars to be max level (1299) you will have to do a good amount of grinding if you want it fast. The Crew would be a lot better if Ubisoft didn't sit around sucking its own♥♥♥♥♥♥all day and actually fixed the problems in a timely manner, but none the less its a fun game. I'd reccomend getting it on sale, and trying the demo first.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												I know this game gets a little bit of hate but honestly, i think it's worth a buy if you're into racing games or a driving sim kind of games. 1st off, the map is huge. If you drive at maximum speed, you can possibly make it from new york to los angeles in 55 mins. If you drive the normal speed limit, expect a good 4-5 hour car journey. There is a lot to see and explore and visit, you really aren't limited as to where you can go. If you want to drive through a forrest in the middle of nowhere, you can do that. If you want to get lost in the desert, you can do that, if you want to slide down ski slopes on high mountains, you can do that. You can't get out your car which is a down side but it is a car game so that's expected. I personally love this game. I may not have many hours on it but i will eventually when i get around to playing it a lot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												The Crew has it issues like sudden crashes (but that’s expected being a UBISOFT PC game) but even then they don't happen often, but what really bugs me is how you can be free driving and all of a sudden you run through a mini-game challenge, sometimes you can simply swerve out of the way but on small road with guard rails it’s impossible not to go through them, you then have to click ESC and abort it which completely ruins the experience. Now they can be helpful for gaining parts and XP but it would be nice if you could avoid them. I think my only other big issue in this game is if you get in close proximity to an item (im guessing a collectible to get the hidden car) the radar starts this infernal bleeping noise that will not stop unless you drive away. I also have some smaller issues with the gameplay being that although they saved us from tailing and time missions in ACU they just couldn’t help adding some off road tailing and takedown missions which I might add are really hard to do due to the weird off road physics that if you go over a bump your truck goes vertical and when it lands it swerves. Also I know it’s a racing game but I can’t help but feel they could have put a bit more diversity in the missions. Some good points are for the most parts the physics are good, the driving is also very responsive and it feels good to take turns and show off, the graphics are stunning, the car selection is decent and the joy I receive from just driving around and exploring the huge map really makes the game for me. And although there are micro-transactions thankfully they are not vital to completing the game. Last thing I’ll say is that you don’t have to join an online crew with real people or play the missions with other players, it can be played completely single player, I’m sure this is well known but at the time I purchased the game I didn’t know and the information would have been helpful in my decision. So I think at the core like all UBISOFT games it’s a really good game and defiantly worth paying, especially if you’re into open world racing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Honestly I really think more people need to appreciate this game for what it is. Everyone's always so caught up in what games have better graphics/framerate/etc. From what I gather, neither of those things are Ivory Tower's goal. What they truly HAVE accomplished with The Crew is successfully piecing together an enjoyable game with nice cars and a gigantic map. And aside from that, they're still supporting the game a whole year after release with new cars, handling improvements, and now an entire graphical overhaul. It's clear that the developers are making their best effort to succeed in all categories. In my unpopular opinion, that's what matters the most.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Here's everything I wish people would've told me about this game while I debated buying it, summarized from most to least important:-From a complete simulator geek obsessed with race sims, on hardcore mode with a Logitech G27, the physics lean much more towards simcade than arcade. In fact, the physics remind me a lot of Gran Turismo 4, with much better low speed differential physics (aka you can actually do a proper donut)-The vehicle upgrades can be used to vastly impact vehicle handling, and if the car feels unrealistic, swapping around differential parts and tires makes a huge difference, and can make an upgraded car that feels arcade-y, to VERY sim feeling.-If you own a Logitech G27 and you don't own this game, WHAT ARE YOU DOING WITH YOUR LIFE?-It's the TRUE spiritual successor to Test Drive Unlimited, and you should forget TDU2 ever existed.-While the graphics resembles TDU2 (same lead environment artist, who is now employed by Rockstar) NOTHING ELSE DOES, SO FEAR NOT, that POS game can be forgotten and/or nuked into eternity.-The developers who created this game LOVED it, and it shows.Tips: -If you have a low end processor, turn geometry settings down. The visual impact is minimal (a little more pop in) and it will vastly boost your FPS-If you have a low end GPU, turn Ambient Occlusion to SSAO or off.-If you love race sims, have a wheel, you NEED to buy this game. PERIOD.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I honestly don't understand the rage here. There are problems sure, but you're not going to find anything close to this game for PC, period. I'd describe it as Euro Truck Simulator meets NFS Undercover (older version, not the remake junk).THE BADThe "crewpoints" or whatever they are system. Yeah the publishers have hopped onto the in-game purchase bandwagon, and I don't agree with this nickle-and-dime system outside of free Appstore games,  but it's not implemented in an annoying or necessary-to-play kind of way. I'm only 18 hrs into the game and have some junk car I started out with (sorry Ford), an upgraded mid-range car, and a beautiful Italian supercar I take out on special occasions. They even give you 100k credits after an early mission, more than enough to get you started.  I haven't touched the credit system beyond that, but even if I wanted to, it would be a few bucks for a new car and some random customization. Considering I got the game for 30-35 bucks, a fiver added onto that one time isn't really a huge problem.This always-online crap is the future, and it sucks. But I haven't had connectivity problems, so I can tolerate it. The community isn't huge, so PVP games aren't easy to come by in my 18 hour experience, but I enjoy playing the missions and just crusing around, exploring. And you'll always find someone running from the police or available to ram into (sorry, I do it with love). That said, impromptu street races and roadtrips would be pretty sweet, but maybe I just need more friends...THE GOODThe map! The open-world! Way too much to explore! While it's not totally accurate and all-encompassing, the ability to drive around major cities in most every region of the US (Alaska and Hawaii, sorry bros) is something I've dreamed of ever since I got into driving games. And it's implemented perfectly here. Plenty of roads to take across the US, varying in driving complexity and scenery, and I never feel as though I'm trapped or limited by a wall. The exception would be the actual wall seperating Mexico and Texas. Bush wasn't kidding.The graphics are fantastic. A friend jokes that it doesn't take much for racing games to look good, and while true, the scenery is a joy to look at. They even have a "photo mode" because they know we're snapping screenshots. Even on my paltry Macbook Pro settings, I really enjoy looking at the game. The handling is perfect for an arcade racer, which is what this is. I play serious racing sims but can also suspend my pretentious ways to enjoy games like this and NFS. If only Just Cause 3 borrowed these phyiscs...THE MEDIOCRERubberbanding is annoying and while this game isn't horrible with it, if your car is underpowered for a race and you make one mistake, you're restarting. Even missions where you're supplied the car, no matter the lead you have, one or two mistakes in this case can cost the 5-minute race. I've got a mission in the latter that I cannot beat, even 18 hours into the game, and it's holding me back from new missions down that path.There aren't enough missions. This is an "MMORPG" (MMORG?). I don't mind grinding a bit to earn money/levels. But I worry I may eventually run out of ways to advance. There are events, and challenges while driving, but that may not be enough to sustain constant advancement. I'd even settle for "collect the tires on the racetrack" type stuff.I love cars and customization, but there just isn't enough here. While I was able to get the two main cars I shoot for every racing game, I'd love to see more older vehicles and some of the newer supercars (why no Veyron?). I mean, why is there an Escalade and a Hummer? This isn't Cruisin USA. Give me more Ferraris, a Countach, and Porches (come on, RUF??) The visual customization is pretty bare. There are quite a few colors and they allow you to customize all of the typical areas of the car, but the choices aren't enough, and aren't significant in differences. I've got to frequently switch back and forth between parts to spot the difference. But honestly, even if I were running around in a Ford Pinto, I'd have fun exploring the map.TLDRAll said, this is a solid arcade racer, enough cars and customization to enjoy the experience (though I'd like more), beautiful scenery and graphics, but most of all: THE FANTASTIC, FREE-ROAM MAP OF EVERY REGION IN THE CONTINENTIAL US. If that sounds good, buy the game. As of current, make sure you get the Wild Ride or whatever version. It comes with the original game and the expansion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Why do I reccomend this game? It's not the cars, the driving, or story. It's the atmophere. The whole game is breathing, it's full of activity, people, cars, and even planes and helicopters. People can be seen jogging in hot climates, people in the snow wear jackets, some even have conversations. Cities are full of cars, with not so bad AI too! Planes are the biggest part in my opinion. If you see a farm a cropduster will occasionally fly over. Helicopters buzz about like ants, some tiny and some small. Planes can land and take off from airports. (Which you can actually go to and use) They all have their own sounds and lights. If you like taking in the scenery, I would reccomend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Do I recomend this game? Yes, and no.The story is boring and repetitive. The AI is way too easy, you win every race with minimal effort. You complete some section, then you move on to another section, where you do the same thing, with a different tuner. The difficulty doesnt go up. You move to a different place, you get another character you dont care about, everybody tries to look fierce, blah blah blah blah blah.  The police are too easy, and too hard at the same time. If they get you trapped for 3 seconds, even though you are clearly getting un-trapped, you get arrested. But if they didnt trap you, they barely stay on you. Seriously, it is way too easy to lose them.But the multiplayer makes up for the terrible story. The summit events are always extremly fun, to try to get to silver and gold. The multiplayer races are extremly fun, but get boring fast, when you are playing the same maps. There isnt much different maps. The side missions are also a blast. Freedriver stunts, crew missions, and something else, i cant remeber the name of it xD. This is just kinda a freetime game. This game gets very stale, very fast. Beware.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Ever since Hot Wheels for the Nintendo DS was a thing, I've been playing racing games. But I always wanted more than the invisible wall boundaries and randomly placed cement walls that told me I couldn't go here or there. And then there was Need for Speed Carbon and so on, and I was a happy boy. But, 2 years ago, I saw a trailer for this upcoming game, The Crew. I was blown away! Finally, a game were you could get to explore America in your car, not some stock here-we'll-only-give-you-colors-as-customization-options cars *cough cough* Need for Speed Rivals. But instead, a car that you'd most likely never see anyone else driving. Out of my entire garage, I have never seen someone with the exact same wheels, bumpers, exhaust, interior, vinyls, and so on. And the graphics, long story short, I have never had a harder♥♥♥♥♥♥ But hey, if you're not hard while driving, you probably like men. Of course, running this game in ultra while still getting 60 FPS in dowtown New York comes at a price, which is needing to have a monster of a PC. Your mom's laptop from the office won't run this without burning itslef alive. Overall a great game, and my favorite racing game yet.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												If I could give this game a totally mixed review, I would. I have therefore decided to recommend this game, but only when it's on sale half price, like when I got it.In my experience, the story is forgettable, the missions can get repetitive (and often very difficult) and the 'RPG elements' including car upgrades are severely lacking. I would have loved to see actual individual upgrade purchases, like in the forza games, rather than meaningless stats. I completed the story missions in around 20 hours, playing entirely single player (the game includes worryingly few other players btw), which is feel is a more than acceptable gameplay time.  The thing that redeems the game though (mostly) is the map and the cars... Firstly, i'll talk about the map. Ignore all of the criticism of it being too small, or not very detailed, its amazing. There are enough areas to carry on exploring after the story is completed and driving around is very fun on its own! If free roaming is your thing, then you will love this. The cars, as i've mentioned before, have limited customization when it comes to performance, which is a shame. HOWEVER, you can customize the looks of your cars, from decals, to alloys, to bumpers as much as you want. Also, you can customize a car for each spec you have it tuned to, so effectivley having multiple versions of each car! You can build your favourite cars and then use the in-game photography mode (which is very in-depth) to take pictures wherever you want, with filters, lighting, weather effects etc. This part of the game, however small, can eat up hours if you like getting the perfect screenshot!Overall, this game is somewhat disappointing, when you consider the marketing and what it claims to be.. a driving MMO! If you want a simulation game, or something with hardcore racing, it's definatley not for you. If however, you are a fan of more 'arcadey' racing games, or just want something different to play, I would give it a try. I wouldn't however say it's worth the full price, especially when its plagued with DLC and microtransactions!

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Really fun open world racer. I love the customization, however I do feel nagged to buy in game content with all the purchase things in the car dealership and prompts to upgrade to Wild Run. It is not as great as Forza Horizon 2 on Xbox, but it is by far the closest PC comparison. Cruise the whole US with no one to tell you otherwise. Don't expect the "full US" though, its been shrunken down to major landmarks and cities. Found this out when I tried to look through my home state of Idaho and found nothing, not even the Grand Teton's or West Yellowstone :P. Oh well, still suggested!

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												The Crew in my opinion is the best racing game on the market. The freedom to make up your own fun is one of the best things about the game as you can either play all of the story missions and pve missions or pvp racing. The pve missions have a good selection to play from for all the car specs to earn in game money and rep and some upgrades for your cars and with the addition of the crew wild run awhile ago there is alot more to do and extra cars and specs to have a play around with. With any racing game you find the usual group of racers who either drive dirty but you can easily avoid them but 90% of the time you find all kinds of drivers who are clean drivers and you have fun with as you race or cruise around.The crew is a great game with a race wheel for the people have one or are thinking to get one and a normal controller works great to.

Posted: April 22, 2016
												I gave it a positive, because it IS a fun game. I have even played most of the game solo and it has been a fun experience. However, that being said the amount of cars that you can buy with in game credits is disapointingly small. Most of the good cars you have to buy with real $. When you spend a good amount of $ on the game then more on the Wild Rund dlc, (without the Wild Run, the game would not be fun imo) its a huge letdown that they make you spend so much more on extra cars. If here was a bigger selection of cars inclused with the games I would not have any agrument, but that is not so.  I have not paid any extra for cars and it still has been fun, thus the thumbs up. But if i was to rate it 1-10 I would have to give it a 6 because of the cars issue. If you can get the game plus Wild Run for a good price, I recomend it. If not pass it up or wait untill you can.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												loved it for a few days, then it stopped working. Ubisoft... ♥♥♥♥ing fix this if you don't want to lose customersUPDATEsolution found: http://forums.ubi.com/showthread.php/1302898-The-Crew-has-stopped-working/page3Actual Review: Now that I've played this game for 100+ hours i think i can make a good judgement. Overall i ♥♥♥♥ing love this game, It's a great game to play with your friends from taking a roadtrip across America to going through a adrenaline filled hot pursuit *NEW GADGETS AVALIABLE FOR POLICE CHASES* at high speeds. Although I wish it had steam achievements it doessn't which to be honest is usually a turn off when buying games because I'm an absolute achievement hunter. This game has a special feel to it compared to other racing games. The detailed environment gives you an extra sense of being there and the amazing diversity of cars makes you feel like the richest racer in the world. Although Ubisoft (as usual) is begging for money with the DLCs being extremely overpriced although they are still extremely fun and add crazy amounts of new content such as a whole new mini story (in ways) with the new Calling All Units DLC. Pros: -Great Graphics-Diverse veichle choice and customizability-Huge amounts of free roam-There is an incredible amount of things to do in this game with over 100 hours i havent even completed 30%-Constant online championships-Reasonable price for the game-my friend said its better than forza horison 3 (i dont believe him tho)-probably lots more i can't think ofCons:-Need a really good computer-DLCs are overpriced-the gravity stops you from doing barrel rolls-if you don't get the CAU DLC zoe tells you to get an unlockable car every 5 minutes-probably lots of other things i can't thing of right now

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												This game is kinda good only if you don't do story and didn't set controls to hardest ones without having a racing wheel.(since several cars suck at handling too much...) Buy it only on discounts!(since it costs too much...)Main review part:Graphics: Good but they eat too much so i have to play on medium to not to lag @10 fps :x (8/10)Gameplay: It's kinda good, but some moments are too bad (when you have to rekt someone for example)(7/10)Controls: Menu navigation sux, car handling: okay, but not realistic(ice+any OP car=powersliding 24/7, but if we go "nub mode" and set full assist, we don't powerslide -.-) (5/10)Story: Good for NFS, not good for everything else xD at least no unethical♥♥♥♥♥♥so its okay... (6/10)Setting: 1:50(i think) scale USA is kinda cool, and a lot of cars to choose... (10/10)End-Game playability: Best part of this game is endgame cuz you have much todos and PvP, but.. that means grinding which is not good in racing kind of games...(parts for example) (7/10)Overall rating: Game is kinda decent, but overpriced and you must rush thru story to get to interesting part... Btw there is some other alternative to it which is much betr, but has no nfs stuff, its Test Drive Unlimited 2... kinda decent time waster, so try it out too! (much cheaper. but those edays dev support is almost nothing :c)Rank: B (7,1/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												I'll start off by saying this game is a lot of fun, by yourself or playing with friends. The handling is very arcadey, but still has a good balance between grip and sliding. The physics are really bad. Like really bad. But that isn't a game killer. It just looks kinda funky when your car gets launched into the air. Customization is limited and there really aren't a lot of cars to choose from. It seems like there is about 25. Which in an open world car game there won't really be anything that makes you a unique driver compared to everyone else in your world. Which is a disappointment. No 'forza style' painting on your car, you just select preset liveries and thats that...But is it fun? Hell ya. The soundtrack is pretty damn good. Not on par with the lights of forza horizon bass arena, but still good. Is it worth $40?? (you have to get wild run dlc for this game to be any decent at all) Probably not. It only takes 20 hours to finish the single player and reach level cap.. that's $2 an hour in a massive game that could easily been designed for 100+ hours of story driven gameplay. The missions are repetitive and cheesy. The dialogue is insanely cheesy, although acted very well. SHOULD YOU BUY? No. unless its $20 for wild run dlc and full game. WOULD I RECOMMEND? Yes. It is fun, but lacks content to really be a stellar game. 7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												The singleplayer aspect of this game is a bit boring. The story seems rushed. However, just like the trailer, I feel like this game is not meant to be played alone and is meant to be played in a crew. The people I've met in PvP events are by far one of the friendliest community in a video game. Just cruising with high end cars from New York City to Los Angeles just talking to the people online makes this game so enjoyable. As for cars, I like the variety. Although it is not close to the amount of cars in say Gran Turismo or Forza, just upgrading a mustang into a Monster spec is so satisfying. You could also win DLC vehicles from special events, which gives an incentive to play more. Furthermore, they keep updating and releasing more specs for cars. This is by far not the best game I've played; however, it is my favorite racing game.

												Pros: very big map, nice graphic at lowest setting, smart loot enable to get better part at lower level race, nice cutscene, nice story line, nice kits for car, nice scenery and detail at background.Cons: smart loot give me ♥♥♥♥♥♥ part which is much worse (eg. +2 performance) compare to gold (eg. +20 performance) on the event with a car with stock or low level part on the slot. worst game inefficient game processing low fps everytime only get 60 fps at the last moment of the race. crown race is so boring and annoying. game always crash or lag the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of my pc I7 with GT755 SLI. nfs rival look and played much better with high setting at 60 fps. everytime pvp the map never be the same so my pc need to load the new map which take like the whole race with 10 fps is the worse even with a max performance car. experience time lag when my pc lag (eg. game time is slower than real time. drive on a straight path still lose to a much lower performance car with no lag)What can the developer do : make the game run smoother or require lesser pc performance etc. smart loot will give the gold part of the event if the part on the car is lower performaance than the gold part.

content:

												This game really defines "Open World" arcade racing games but was executed poorly. The massive game world set in United State really is beautiful and scenic but the gameplay is mediocre at best. It's fun for a day or two when exploring the game world but the gameplay is bland after you had experienced enough. Nevertheless, I cannot recommend this game for those who are fans of racing games but if you want to experience something different from the normal racing games set in a small arena, Then this is for you TL;DR Game world is massive and beautifulGameplay is mediocreRecommended playing with friends Hype is dangerous

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												Edit: Okay, Wild Run has been released and the game is 'fully' out, so here's my honest review.Pros:+Great graphics (This game is beautiful and well-optimized)+Massive car selection, which is still being expanded+5 specs, including dirt/raid which most games don't think about+Wild Run includes bikes and extreme specs, which most games don't think about either (Drift Cars, Drag Racers, and Monster Trucks)+Realistic physics (For the most part, at least)+Lots of wheel-based settings in case you drive with a wheelCons:-Still some bugs that will ♥♥♥♥ up your driving-PvP isn't very balanced-Pricing ($90 to buy everything seperately)-Wild Run not worth the moneyConclusion: Great game, but the expansions seem a bit too expensive. Wait for a sale and then pick it up at a discount. Very worth it otherwise. 9/10

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												The game is fun, don't get me wrong, but it has its drawbacks. The costumization is great, the cars are sweet, and the variety is great. I've never played a racing game that has a Ferrari 458, and a 2010 Chevy SIlverado. The map is awsome. Instead of being stuck in one city, you can cross the entire U.S. The cities aren't perfect, or even close for that matter, but if you play the game in the right mind set, where nothing is perfect, you'll have fun. I enjoy the game, it's not the best game, but its good. It's an arcade driving game, not a simulation racing like Forza or Assetto Corsa.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Car sounds are awful, completely different to the actual sounds each model produces IRL.The game IS big, yes... but it lacks THINGS to do. Could have more user interaction outside of the specific racing ambient. Also needs at least twice the number of cars available.Maximum of 8 people (seriously!!!!) per instance, that means you'll see no more than 8 people at a time anywhere you go ingame.Game forces you to rice your car. You can't just upgrade the engine and keep the car with a clean look. Just lowering the suspension a bit and changing the wheels? Nope you MUST choose one of the ridiculously huge spoilers, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hoods AND keep the car looking like a scared cat, high up to the sky.Handles like a game that was not made for racing in the first place. Your FWD or AWD cars burnout on rear wheels lmaoThis game is expensive as hell for what it delivers, and just to keep ruining the experience, it has microtransactions!I got it on a 40% off and regret doing so. Would not recommend the purchase if the discount isn't at 75% or more.Story was decent, graphics are decent. Race events are fun, that's it.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This is a very fun game.  While the storyline missions are forgettable, there are tons of side activities to accomplish and are very fun to play with friends.  The map of the U.S. is awesome.  You can go ANYWHERE on the map.  You can drive up the side of a mountain and overlook big cities such as LA and NYC.  The atmosphere of the game leaves you with a nice comfy feel.  Nothing beats driving across the U.S. in your favorite cars with your buddies.  All the cars are fun to drive and feature many details.  There are some bugs with AI traffic and some technical difficulties with Ubi's garbage network 'features'.  Overall would recommend.  8/10

												Awesome game.  Thats all I have to say.I was debating buying it recently, however when it went on sale for 50% off, I decided to purchase gold edition because of the bonus items/features it came with. The story line also makes it even more enjoyable, and the fact that you can play it online with others if you want.  The map is massive, which also adds to the enjoyment of even just driving around with no reason.Yes, there are a few flaws to the game, however they have not negatively affected my personal experience playing it.I can guarantee the dedication of many, many more hours to the game.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Game is really fun. If you like arcade racing games it is a must have.Pros:-The way the car drives is pretty customizable and even though you can't make huge changes like making it a sim, you can definitely make it drive to your taste (as long as you enjoy arcade driving).-Game creates the perfect challange. You can win most races with relative ease, but getting that gold medal definitely requires some skill.-People have been bashing the graphics, but for an online-focused open world racing game the graphics are really impressive.-Online experience seems pretty stable. One problem I always have with online racing games is how crazy things go when playing online, cars popping out of nowhere, suddenly stoping or accelarating, etc. So far I have experienced no major problems while playing coop events.-Variety of car classes and events for those classes. There are car classes build for different terrains and conditions and events for those different classes.-Don't like playing with other people? You can go completely solo. Even though the game is online-focused you can ignore everyone around you and play it like if it was a singleplayer game.-Even though it's an arcade game you can feel the differences in handling of each vehicle with ease, making car choices come to preference.-That huge map! Travelling from one city to another is already a lot of fun and there are kind of mini-games in every road that include jumping, slaloms, driving fast and on the road, etc. All to keep you busy on your travels while also rewarding you.-The performance is flawless. Some people may be worried about performance since it's a Ubisoft game, but I have a pretty old computer and can still run the game flawlessly with mixed high/ultra settings.Neutral:-There are not many visual customization options as I though there would be, but customizing your car is still pretty fun, even though I feel it could be better.-Soundtrack doesn't fit the game well. The songs don't give you that adrenaline that make you want to drive fast and recklessly. But I believe no one cares for game soundtracks anymore, since most people just mute the game music and use an external music player.-The story feels kinda dull. The story is amazing the first minutes of gameplay, but once you hit the road it doesn't feel like a big deal anymore, but all online-focused games are like this. I haven't completed the game yet, so take this one with a grain of salt.-Cops are lazy. You have to do some real♥♥♥♥♥♥for them to go after you, just driving a clearly illegaly modified car 100Km/h above speed limit won't do it. Some people will love it, some others will hate it. Sometimes they also appear during races and don't do anything. In events where they're the main deal it's a different story, of course.Cons:-The car sounds are pretty bad, they just don't sound reallistic. Sometimes I feel like hearing an engine that came from a 2005 game.-You win performance parts in every event, which completely makes the performance shop useless allowing you to make a lot of money very easily since you have to spend very little of it to progress through the game. Remember that I haven't completed the game yet, it may change at some point.-You can't play the game offline, as far as I know. People who don't have access to a decent connection all the time must be very careful when buying this game.Some people have been saying this game is horrible, it is not. I haven't experienced bugs, lags, freezes, ctds or anything like that. The game is just great, even though it's not amazing. It's a great game that will give you a lot of fun specially if you play with your friends, but there's nothing really groundbraking about it.Also, don't pay attention to those people saying that the game's handling and physics are horrible. It's an arcade game and it was designed to be so, so don't expect reallistic collisions, steering, car damage or anything like that. It has very good mechanics for an arcade game. It's not just an "accelerate and steer game" and you can still make mistakes in it, considering that you're playing on hardcore mode.I give this game a solid 7.8/10If you have any doubts if you should or should not buy the game, feel free to ask me any questions ; )

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Well I will keep it short and sweet. This game is hands down a lot of fun. When I say fun I mean sit on my♥♥♥♥♥until it starts to sting and hurt because the cushions on my chair are so worn. NOW THATS FUN...Anyways, This game is a HUGE open world. Anyone complaining its not to scale or a exact copy of google maps or something can go shove it. The graphics are great and with the MMO structure there is endless room for improvement with later content patches.. even to the very items and cars of the game to gamemodes. and for a Ubisoft title on PC the launch did very well haha.I have no problem finding 2 or 3 players to do a few missions with. I have already made a few friends in game. The gameplay is simple yet extremely satisfying. You complete missions and get essentially "loot" from doing it and level up. There are also random missions along the roads and paths that give you parts and upgrades.Also there is tiers of levels and factions for end game. I mean this game is huuge and for 60 bucks its totally worth it to me. I mean its the most fun ive had on a game in a while.. I mean it had me out of my chair screaming over voice chat with 2 other guys after 4 trys on the same hard mission for the gold and then we did it and it rocked.... sorry for rambling  BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW! it rocks.PS... add me up if you join up always looking to expand my roster of friends to play this game with :]

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												PRO TIP: If you are having trouble enjoying the game because of the handling model, you can fix that by changing the Control settings in the options. Changing it from "All assists" to "Sport" will make it feel like you have much more control over the car. Setting the steering speed factor all the way to the right will make it feel a lot less sluggish when turning. Setting sensitivity a bit to the right can also help.During the beta, I found the handling to feel much better after doing this and enjoyed the game quite a lot. Currently playing the full game, and it's just as effective.

												The crew. The game might look like something horrible at first or in the tralirs but I can tell you right now that this game is not horrible. The crew is about you trying to seek vengiens for your brothers death. But in the mean time while trying to do that many problems occur. Once you are done with all 50 levles(60 soon to come) the game is not over. You can add cars to your collection do pvp and do the summit to have a chance to win a amazing car. And this game is also online all the time. So you are always playing with players and can make friends. Also this game has wheel support.  Its not the best but Once you get the hang of it It works pretty well. Also all the expansiions/dlcs are  amazing. They add so much to the game. And the best part is that you can get chaced by cops and get to 5 starts and just keep on causing cayous. So get this game. Its worth every penny. SO GET RACING!!!!!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Let start off on a very clear thing, I like the crew. I have loved it ever since I heard of it, when it came avalible for pre order, I bought it, then went out and bought parts to make sure my computer could handle it. I still like it, getting into a car and just driving across the huge landscape is just extreamly relaxing and thrilling at times.With that being said, I highly recommend you -DO NOT- buy this game. Ubisoft has been for some time trying to be worse than EA in jackassery, and they have somehow suceeded very well. As pointed out by the other reviews, season pass effects nothing with Wild Run, a forced update and major expanshion that the game now prettymuch relies on and costs as much as the normal game, dispite only giving you limited content. [Four new class types and new event zones mainly] If you are able to pick this game up dirt cheap, sure, go for it, the aimless driving is fun, but that is all that this game offers now, aimless driving. I hate Need for Speed, but you'd be highly better off buying one of them, and that hurts for me to admit that. I really believed in this game, and if it wasn't for ubisoft, I believe this TDU3 could of really shown.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												EXTREMELY RECOMMENDEDI bought this game on UPLAY at Day One (Nov. 2014), and just bought the Steam version again PROS+2 Good Graphic, acceptable for a game released in late 2014+10 This game has the Largest Real World Map in the whole video game industry (FUEL or Daggerfall is larger but full of emptiness)+2 Great Optimization, can play at stable 60FPS max setting even the map is extremely big+2 A considerable amount of cars to drive+2 Years of DLC support with reasonable pricetags+2 Varitey types of vehicles to drive, they merge the idea of "class" from RPG to a racing game, there are Street, Dirt, Raid, Circuit, Drag, Bike, Monster Truck and Police classes of cars, pretty fun+3 A very tradinational story mode with at least 40 hours of play time+4 They do not fill the maps with emptiness, it's fun to just free roam, it will take you around 1 hour and a half to drive from one side of the map to another, also there a infinite numbers of skill challenge areas and a long lasting Summit Event (Wild Run DLC), Police Control (Calling All Units DLC)), I am very very impressive with that+3 Soundtrack is exciting and memorable, very well produced+3 Very Affordable Price for a good game like thisCONS-8 False Advertising, It's not a MMO, it is only a MO, you can only play with players that are in the same session with you, only around 20 players per map, due to the size of the map is way too large, you can not encounter any other players, if you want to play a Racing MMO, it is not your choice-3 Mirco-transcation is huge, cars with CC are expensive, in game credits are hard to earn-5 Online Racing is sometimes glitching due to UBI's laggy serverFINAL RATING+17BTW: NEED FOR SPEED 2015 IS GARBAGE, BUY THIS GAME INSTEAD!RATING SYSTEM BASED ON GAMING EXPERIENCEAbove 15: Extremely Recommended+9 - +15 Highly Recommended+0 - +8 Recommended-5 - -1 Not Recommended-6 - -10 Lame as CrapLess than -10: Wasting your life playing this game, please withdraw it from Steam

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												EXTREMELY RECOMMENDEDI bought this game on UPLAY at Day One (Nov. 2014), and just bought the Steam version again PROS+2 Good Graphic, acceptable for a game released in late 2014+10 This game has the Largest Real World Map in the whole video game industry (FUEL or Daggerfall is larger but full of emptiness)+2 Great Optimization, can play at stable 60FPS max setting even the map is extremely big+2 A considerable amount of cars to drive+2 Years of DLC support with reasonable pricetags+2 Varitey types of vehicles to drive, they merge the idea of "class" from RPG to a racing game, there are Street, Dirt, Raid, Circuit, Drag, Bike, Monster Truck and Police classes of cars, pretty fun+3 A very tradinational story mode with at least 40 hours of play time+4 They do not fill the maps with emptiness, it's fun to just free roam, it will take you around 1 hour and a half to drive from one side of the map to another, also there a infinite numbers of skill challenge areas and a long lasting Summit Event (Wild Run DLC), Police Control (Calling All Units DLC)), I am very very impressive with that+3 Soundtrack is exciting and memorable, very well produced+3 Very Affordable Price for a good game like thisCONS-8 False Advertising, It's not a MMO, it is only a MO, you can only play with players that are in the same session with you, only around 20 players per map, due to the size of the map is way too large, you can not encounter any other players, if you want to play a Racing MMO, it is not your choice-3 Mirco-transcation is huge, cars with CC are expensive, in game credits are hard to earn-5 Online Racing is sometimes glitching due to UBI's laggy serverFINAL RATING+17BTW: NEED FOR SPEED 2015 IS GARBAGE, BUY THIS GAME INSTEAD!RATING SYSTEM BASED ON GAMING EXPERIENCEAbove 15: Extremely Recommended+9 - +15 Highly Recommended+0 - +8 Recommended-5 - -1 Not Recommended-6 - -10 Lame as CrapLess than -10: Wasting your life playing this game, please withdraw it from Steam

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												If the Need for Speed franchise is tyring to get back to their roots (and I have completed the newest game) they really need to look to these guys for inspiration as this game does a much better job of mixing a good motive to get you started as well as keeping to many of the gameplay elements that made older need for speed games legendary. Having domination and customization at its core. As well, This game is ambitious to say the least, mapping the entire U.S.A to a scale that offers a surprizing veriety of locations to visit and scout. After a year they looked to reinvigorate the game by releasing a sort of overhauling DLC, adding new mechanics, game modes, and vehicle types, Even updating the graphics with new textures and weather effects. the DLC costs $30 but the base game has been reduced putting the whole game with the new overhaul somewhere around 40 - $50, which is well worth the entry for a great example of how to handle an aging brand without pumping out another game within an unrealistic deadline. The mechanics and physics are not on par with the best of the old Need for Speed arcade type open world racer, they feel very loose and a bit unpredictable at times, but for the overall experience the handling gets a pass by me. the open world and storyline feel overarcing and important, something we sorely lack in AAA titles these days, A sense of importance. One problem that holds this game back is the fact that it is set up as an MMO, which means microtransactions, which means spiked economy costs for things that a singleplayer would allow within much more reasonable values, if it were a singleplayer game it would probably have a much longer story and a much bigger payoff to upgrading cars and progressing, but instead we have every car roughly as fast as eachother and performance upgrades unlocking in a random loot counter sort of setup wich makes buying upgrades almost pointless. Just one example of how MMO is most often not the way to go with your game. I think the game would have greatly benefited on being singleplayer focused while having the same online components it already does, the MMO features in the core game are like any other AAA game that tries to go MMO, theyre pointless, its immerssion breaking, its economy stifling, it simply doesnt work. So I give this game a 7/10 (Buy instead of that new NFS)For a person whos played just about every racer under the sun, its a good game to have around if you want to play around in, from time to time, or just see the sites of the U.S in game form.

content:
Posted: April 20
												Let me preface this review by saying I am a huge fan of motorsports and racing games. I was a junior in High school when Gran Turismo 4 launched back in ’05 and it was the sole reason I bought a PS4 that I had saved for from my part time job working at the 99 cent store. On the weekends my friend and I would take shifts driving the 24 hour endurance races. Over the years I have spent many hours playing other “less serious” racing games as well, from everything with the title “Need For Speed” or “Midnight club”; after what I can only assume are thousands of hours spent playing racing games when I started playing “The Crew” I was a bit confounded. This may contain some spoilers.The Crew boasts a wide array of vehicles and specs to choose from; everything from street spec tuner cars, performance muscle cars, bikes, dragsters, drifters, off road rally type vehicles and even the occasional monster truck. With lots of visual customization options to boot, on the surface, it seems like something very similar to midnight club. 	The game starts you off driving an American classic, a ’69 Camaro, and for reasons I don’t quite recall you end up working for the police trying to infiltrate a gang, I think they killed my cousin or something? It’s not really memorable or engaging, but in order to really get money to get cars and unlock new specs you let the story lead you around Detroit, Chicago, New York and then Miami, and after about 13 hours in, I didn’t feel like I was really playing a racing game at all. Sure there are some races sprinkled in the story and they seem more like an afterthought as you spent most of your time trying to beat the clock in point to point missions to spy on your friend. 	By this point in the game I had done some exploring of all the content the game had to offer including police chasing me in my ’67 Shelby GT 500 (yes it is silver) running crates to get car parts to unlock a Bentley and make some cash. I had replayed some story mode races, I even tried some PVP, which was not a race like you might think but a game of capture the flag , or king of the hill , I wasn’t really sure. While wondering around Key West, longing for the game to feel more like a race game then a badly written police drama I stumbled upon a faction mission; A race from Miami to LA! The info about the mission said it would take 2.5 hours! Would it feel like a real race I wondered? I accepted it and off to LA I was in my Dirt Spec’d Ford Focus (in retrospect, not a car I wanted to spend 2 hours in). Fighting our way through Miami Traffic the race was on! And with really no clear indication of where I was headed other than north after about 20 minutes of racing I was in New York, I think. I didn’t really have time to scope out the landmarks while continually trading 1st and 2nd position with another Focus; however, even this fight for the lead didn’t really seem to matter, because in order to complete this mission you only have to place 3rd or better, and there was only 4 cars, you just couldn’t be last, which didn’t seem to be an issue, because the mini in last didn’t seem interested in holding any other position. Another 20 or so minuets and I was driving past Mt Rushmore. Not really sure I felt like I was racing at all, but just investing time into the game to get the 160,000 purse from finishing the mission. 	Turning south and driving through the South West badlands I was trying to come to terms with what this game really was, or find some justification for finishing this race, yet as I came upon the Grand Canyon and hit some seriously long stretches of dirt road I was having fun sliding my little focus around the corners trying to go as fast as I could. Heading north again, towards the Sierra Nevada Mountains I started to think, in spite of everything the game tries to offer it still does not feel like an actually racing game but rather a showcase of motorsport competitions, and tributes to various car movies, like the Fast and the Furious or gone in 60 seconds. Finally as I was blasting down the Pacific coast highway towards Malibu I released “The Crew” is actually a love letter to everything motorsport, unfortunately that letter is written in crayon and authored by Ubisoft.

												The Crew Is a game that you might love or hateit's really fun when you 1st play it but it can get a bit boring later if you kept playing aloneI personally have over 500 hours on the ps4 version and 42 hours on the pc versionPros :+Huge Map+Decent story+Handling Feels a little bit realistic (you have to switch to hardcore mode through the settings to turn off assists)+wheel support+PvP Races Are really fun+It Has customizations+Good Car list+cockpit view+You can spend good Hours alone before getting bored+Super fun if you have friends to play with+Decent graphics (It'll look 100 times better + weather with the upcoming november update)+Huge Post-release support+nice easter eggs around the mapCons :-Can get boring Alone-You can only see up to 7 other players at once-PvP Races are unbalanced-You have to grind a bit to get a decent car-dull soundtrack-FFB Is too powerful off-road. the wheel will go crazy even if you set the ffb to 1-Cops feel off-ZERO Sense of speed-Uplay requiredI give this game 7.8/10 (no that's not an ign reference xD)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												I really enjoyed "The Crew" and its downloadable contents, mainly for its great open world—the reproduction of the whole United States in a smaller version.Every time I play the game, I am surprised how detailed the environment and the cities really are.Although there are game objects (like houses in small towns around the world map) which do actually appear quite often, it still is fascinating how many different buildings and environmental structures (deserts, mountains, snow landscapes) there are and how it affects the playstyle, giving the player various opportunities to enjoy the game in very different ways.The car selection in the game is good, all in all. If you want great cars however, you almost have to spend real money on as The Crew's in-game currency adds up extremely slowly.The multiplayer functionalitites of the game are fine overall. However, the game's genre would be more accurate without the "Massive" in "Massively Multiplayer Online Game". Most of the players on your map are multiple kilometers/miles away from you, but when finding one, it is really fun to drive around with the other player. Also, one thing to criticize is the game's always-online "feature". Playing the game when the servers are offline, which happens quite frequently, is impossible. I would like it even more if there was an offline mode, making it possible to play alone and without any active online connection.Moving on to the game's story, it is basically like in any other MMO-type racing game. Without spoiling its contents: Not too interesting, but kind of okay. You get phone calls from different people, have to drive to a specific point on a map and have to clear a specific mission. That's it.Ubisoft's DLC policy for The Crew (unlike any other of this publisher's games) is now kind of fair. You get the game for a pretty low price and the two major DLC packages (Calling all Units, including Wild Run) for a decent amount as well—compared to other games, at least. This however does not include all of the car packs, which are ridiculously expensive.The two major DLCs for the game are pretty good, actually, as they add new game mechanics like bikes or even a completely new police mode.Overall, I think that The Crew is a great game to get, mainly due to its open world features. But if you're looking for a racing game that completely focuses on the racing part, you probably want to get another game.The term which would sum up what The Crew is like would probably be "Need for Speed, but with better online features and a more interesting map".

												Pro`s:Good funGreat variety of vehiclesMassive map with some great scenic areasPretty well optimisedPlenty to do thanks to a variety of races and challenges (love the monster truck challenges and offroad dirt races)Active online playersPlenty of vehicle customisation (Paintwork, body work, performance etc)Cons:The Ubi launcher (not a deal breaker, but seriously Ubisoft need to ditch it, it is garbage, also not necessary when running through steam)Can`t run people over (yes I get it, this is not GTA)Pay real money in game for some cars (seriously? This is a premium game!) Optional but dumbIn game currency rewards to low (again milked with ability to purchase currency with real money) Again optional but dumbConclusionI really do like this game and the number of hours I have on it is increasing frequently, I fail to understand how they can have the nerve to have microtransactions in a premium game. However they are optional, I choose not to purchase individual additional content or currency with my hard earned. But the game is good arcadey fun with plenty to do in a vast map, I would suggest you shop around though and get a deal on the price like I did.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This is a superb arcade racing sim. Besides the wonderful graphics, and cheeky easter eggs that can be found everywhere, the immensity of the map makes freedriving a pleasure. I've racked up far more time just driving around than actually doing missions and pvp. There is a very large array of the finest cars in the world, which need to be tuned to perfection; although that doesn't necessarily mean that when you max out your car's parts you will have an unbeatable car. PVP is where that definition is put to the test.I don't really like multiplayer games, as they often bring out the worst in people, but I do like playing PVP in The Crew because if you can handle your car, then you have an equal chance of beating any player. Ubisoft should be congratulated for resisting the pay-to-win agenda many publishers turn to, to make a quick buck. Indeed, there are cash cars in the game, but again, they aren't supercars that can destroy all unpaying comers. They are just treats. Like the McLaren F1, which is a beautiful car, but that's it. Put it against the Zonda, and it will run very close; it's a shame they didn't put the Bugatti Veyron in, as then I could relive one of my favourite Top Gear episodes: Veyron vs McLarenThe only problem is a major bug; and I mean major. About 90% of the time when I enter the garage to tune a vehicle, the game will crash. This is maddening, and really screws up the enjoyment of the game, as you often try to avoid going to the garage at all. It's a pretty critical part of the game, as the parts you collect for your car are very delicately weighted against every other part. I'm trying to work out if you can build a much better car by slow grinding from lower levels, rather than just pay for a level 50 part. This takes time and concentration, so when you're analysing your parts and the game crashes, then you reload and can't be bothered, or too scared, to go back into the HQ. I've found if you go into the HQ when you first load the game, the game does not crash with such frequency. But who wants to go to the HQ when you've just loaded the game? Rather you go the garage after racking up a load of parts and then want to compare one against the other. Maybe if Ubisoft patched the game so you could tune your vehicle outside the HQ; the system is technically there in options, but you can't compare parts outside of the HQ.Although this is a massive negative for the game, it does not spoil the enjoyment of the game itself, as there's so much to do. Hone your skills against your friends. Play missions, PVE, Factions Missions, and the PVP arenas of course. Again, I usually shy away from PVP, as this often brings out the worst in people, and if you leave collisions on, then you will quickly run into those people. There is also a trend of people's to harass drivers they encounter by ramming them continually, but, if you can handle your car, then you will not have a problem escaping from these morons; and I think this is just loser rage. In other games this would be a good reason to rage-quit, but I don't mind it so much in The Crew, because if you want the best, you have to beat the worst; and I usually always get the better of them on a circuit track with collisions turned off; and believe me, that's a satisfying feeling, especially if they rage-quit after the race XDYes, this is truly a game I can't get enough of. So thanks Ivory Tower for a great driving experience. And please, don't shut down the server any time soon :)

content:
Posted: April 20
												Let me preface this review by saying I am a huge fan of motorsports and racing games. I was a junior in High school when Gran Turismo 4 launched back in ’05 and it was the sole reason I bought a PS4 that I had saved for from my part time job working at the 99 cent store. On the weekends my friend and I would take shifts driving the 24 hour endurance races. Over the years I have spent many hours playing other “less serious” racing games as well, from everything with the title “Need For Speed” or “Midnight club”; after what I can only assume are thousands of hours spent playing racing games when I started playing “The Crew” I was a bit confounded. This may contain some spoilers.The Crew boasts a wide array of vehicles and specs to choose from; everything from street spec tuner cars, performance muscle cars, bikes, dragsters, drifters, off road rally type vehicles and even the occasional monster truck. With lots of visual customization options to boot, on the surface, it seems like something very similar to midnight club. 	The game starts you off driving an American classic, a ’69 Camaro, and for reasons I don’t quite recall you end up working for the police trying to infiltrate a gang, I think they killed my cousin or something? It’s not really memorable or engaging, but in order to really get money to get cars and unlock new specs you let the story lead you around Detroit, Chicago, New York and then Miami, and after about 13 hours in, I didn’t feel like I was really playing a racing game at all. Sure there are some races sprinkled in the story and they seem more like an afterthought as you spent most of your time trying to beat the clock in point to point missions to spy on your friend. 	By this point in the game I had done some exploring of all the content the game had to offer including police chasing me in my ’67 Shelby GT 500 (yes it is silver) running crates to get car parts to unlock a Bentley and make some cash. I had replayed some story mode races, I even tried some PVP, which was not a race like you might think but a game of capture the flag , or king of the hill , I wasn’t really sure. While wondering around Key West, longing for the game to feel more like a race game then a badly written police drama I stumbled upon a faction mission; A race from Miami to LA! The info about the mission said it would take 2.5 hours! Would it feel like a real race I wondered? I accepted it and off to LA I was in my Dirt Spec’d Ford Focus (in retrospect, not a car I wanted to spend 2 hours in). Fighting our way through Miami Traffic the race was on! And with really no clear indication of where I was headed other than north after about 20 minutes of racing I was in New York, I think. I didn’t really have time to scope out the landmarks while continually trading 1st and 2nd position with another Focus; however, even this fight for the lead didn’t really seem to matter, because in order to complete this mission you only have to place 3rd or better, and there was only 4 cars, you just couldn’t be last, which didn’t seem to be an issue, because the mini in last didn’t seem interested in holding any other position. Another 20 or so minuets and I was driving past Mt Rushmore. Not really sure I felt like I was racing at all, but just investing time into the game to get the 160,000 purse from finishing the mission. 	Turning south and driving through the South West badlands I was trying to come to terms with what this game really was, or find some justification for finishing this race, yet as I came upon the Grand Canyon and hit some seriously long stretches of dirt road I was having fun sliding my little focus around the corners trying to go as fast as I could. Heading north again, towards the Sierra Nevada Mountains I started to think, in spite of everything the game tries to offer it still does not feel like an actually racing game but rather a showcase of motorsport competitions, and tributes to various car movies, like the Fast and the Furious or gone in 60 seconds. Finally as I was blasting down the Pacific coast highway towards Malibu I released “The Crew” is actually a love letter to everything motorsport, unfortunately that letter is written in crayon and authored by Ubisoft.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
The CrewThis is a game I played briefly in Beta and really like the concept of a racing game that lets you travel across the US.  The open world environment allows you to compete in races across the US or just take off and drive anywhere you want from coast to coast without any loading screens. The freedom and choice is yours to make.  Follow the story, venture out and explore, and/or compete in challenges and races. The game feels a lot like Watchdogs if you never left the vehicle only on a larger scale with less people walking around. The vehicles handle similar to the vehicles in Watchdogs intially, but moding them greatly increases performance as you level the car.  Street, dirt, and track veriations of car modifications can be made for all different types of races as well as a large veriety of cosmetic options to customize your ride.  You will not get the sim race track feeling here as the cars are not heavily based on true physics like you would find in the Grid series.  This is definately an arcade style racing game more in line with Need for Speed that provides hours of fun!  Not Just a RacerThe Crew is more than just a traditional racing game.  It is a MMO racing game.  The game is designed to play with other people by joining crews so that you can work together in missions.  Playing with others in your crew provides extra incentives such as experience and cash.  You can put skill points into your bonuses to increase rewards received from playing with your crew members as well as benefits to enhance your car such as reduced repair costs, better breaking, etc. However, the game can be played solo with just as much fun. Weak LinkageAnd here is the weak link in the design of The Crew.  People expecting a MMO will immediately notice that there is no need to join a community to play the game.  The option is there with some rewards but there is no real push to do so. There is also no voice chat built into the game to communicate with your crew members and the pop-up screen is usually hidden to get it out of the way. So even when you do choose to type to crew members, you will seldom get a response. You will find PvE and PvP races/challenges but the need for a community feels absent.  The PvP is fun and I honestly have a blast with some of the game modes.  You will not find any large raid like content here.  It would have been nice to see large cross country races pitting  multiple four man crews against crews or larger 16 plus members competing together in a large scale race against other crews or AI; but what we received was on a much smaller basis for those that want to play solo.  What you will find is a huge open world where you can see people and choose to interact with them or not.  The choice is yours to make. ProsHuge map to ExploreOpen WorldVariety of Race typesVariety of Vehicles/typesVehicle CustomizationGraphicsMMO CommunityConsPhysics are more Arcade than SimWeak MMO CommunityNo voice built in voice chatFinal ThoughtsAfter finishing the game, I still enjoy going back and creating new cars and leveling them up.  I am personally having a blast with this game and recommend it to anyone thats like racing games.   I did not do a first impressions video of this game so I have linked a few videos to give you an idea of what to expect.New Expansion UpdateThe Crew: WIldrun is a DLC expansion coming to the crew with a free overhaul to the graphics and physics engine for all as well as the DLC packed full of quests, races, new race types, vehicles, and vehicle types (monster trucks & motorcycles). It looks amazing!  I cannot wait until November to play it. If only I had a Beta key...For the story:

												This game wasn't worth the purchase for me. If you're looking for a realistic driving multiplayer game, this is not it. Your only solution to evading police or winning races is by driving around them. If you try and push them, you'll slam in to a wall and spin out of control. The fact that cops can drive at impossible speeds and ram you like a wall doesn't help.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												The CrewThe crew is a large, open world environment with lots of multiplayer aspects and huge POTENTIAL. But from there, it’s all a bit downhill. I bought it because I wanted a driving game where you could customise your car, get chased by cops, play with friends even for a nice little drive down a motorway at 200km/h.I got what I asked for, but not what I paid for. I get my custom car, which then gets pulled away from me for mission specific cars. Now, I’m in a mission with an unfamiliar car and AI designed to be perfect. I know they are. Get the perk which shows you the lines to a race mission, I almost guarantee that the AI in 1st will be perfect to that line. Have all the skill you want, if you don’t take shortcuts or have the better car, you won’t win and if that’s the case, don’t even bother going for a perfect score. I know there are people out there who are pros and know every corner, every braking point and every shortcut. I can only imagine how much time they spent and how much sass from the NPCs they got. And then there are the regular AI cars. Not the race ones, just the normal run-of-the-mill pedestrian cars. God help if you’re going for a high score and one of those come along and pull into the lane you’re in about 50m from you.♥♥♥♥♥♥happens, but not to the AI racers.Then the authorities. Hands up all those who love a good chase scene. I do, and I thought “Yeah, lots of road and different terrain, this should be good.” Oh sweet innocence. First, find a patrol car and then crash into stuff. Problem. Find one. I’d hate to believe that there are only two patrol cars in New York. Of course, if you destroy enough stuff, you might initiate a car chase, but only after ruining the front of your vehicle and giving half a city a reason to build a concrete wall as opposed to fences. Of course, you won’t get booked if you ram into all their parked cars unless a patrol car is nearby. Oh and don’t worry about pedestrians either, they’ll jump out of your way while your barrelling down the road at high speeds. You may have noticed I’ve refrained from using the word “cop”. This is because, if you find one on foot, try running him down. He’ll jump out of your way and yell obscenities at you no matter how many times you try. Won’t even call for backup.Multiplayer. Oh boy. My friend and I tried to do a multiplayer session. We attempted about three times with it saying “unable to join crew”. About to give up, we tried once more. *pop*. We’re in lobby together. Okay then, well, we’re in, let’s meet up. We did, or rather, our name tags did. Neither of us could see each other’s car, and we were poorly synced, to the point where I would ram a cop car next to my friend which would proceed to arrest me with my friend laughing because there was nothing there.Hmmm….have I missed something. Oh yes, state of the art graphics from 2011, forced music when in missions (I like my classical), handling which feels like the roads are made of ice and a story which feels like it was pulled out of the “Hat of predictable story lines” with more plot holes in it than the Brony Clopper fandom.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Well, normally I don't write reviews of games, since it's always a personal opinion and a question of wether or not you can live with the faults a game might have. All games have problems, but with the release of the Wild Run DLC, I feel scammed.Originally I pre-ordered the Limited edition of The Crew, setting me back 65€, including season pass and all DLC car packs available at the original release date. After the release of Wild Run, all these have been revoked and needs to be bought once again. That means I have spent around 20€ on something, I will now have to pay for once again. And that's on top of the 25€ I have spent on the Wild Run DLC, which in hindsight I shouldn't have, since they call it a DLC, and therefor it should be part of the The Crew season pass, and not a seperate expansion mini-game, like you would see in other MMOs.Legal or not, the fact that they now force people to buy all the DLCs once againt, this is ethically not something, I want to support. On forums I have seen, that I am not the only one to have experienced this, and with that business model in mind I would not recommend this game.The game itself is suffering from a few bugs, some worse than others, but the most annoying is the endless disconections, usually at the most crucial time during a race.I can live with bugs, but I have a hard time spending money on buying the same game once more.

You can be as idiotic as them for buying this game. The only real reason I ever bought this melarky is because it was on sale. The only reason my play time exceeds 2 hours(Steam's policy for a refund) is because of my perfectionism when playing games. Lo and behold, there was a collectible HotRod you could use after painstakingly searching for them and even so, the HotRod was incredibly not worth the effort.All in all, don't buy it, don't look at it, don't talk about it. - 2/10 "Dissapointing"IGN - 9/10

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Good racing game, reminiscent of Burnout Paradise.  Ubisoft brings a massive wide open world to join up with friends and drive around completing races and winning money.  While it has a few bugs and gripes, it's generally still a fun game.  Playing multiplayer can sometimes have its faults.  Other players' cars will sometimes jostle around the road or almost "vibrate".  Makes it hard to race with friends and stay close to their bumper without hitting them and knocking them off course.  I have been disconnected quite a few times while playing multiplayer, which requires restarting the game to fix.  Hopefully these are all bugs that will be corrected, and not just pushed aside and forgotten when Ubisoft decides to just stop supporting the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												So much potential ruined by greed and Ubisoft's practices.  It's a AAA title you pay full price for, then has all the elements of a F2P title.Pay to win/Pay to progress1)  After buying the game for $40-60, you're given a starting car that is very underpowered and handles like crap.  It takes a *lot* of time to grind out upgrades, level up your character, and earn perks.  OR, you can pay a few real dollars and unlock a super car straight away.  Not with premium currency, *literally* with real world money.  However:2)  There IS premium currency.  You can buy packs of Crew Credits to unlock parts and upgrades faster.This wouldn't be an issue if you could only buy cosmetic things, but the cars on sale for real cash and the parts you can get with premium currency give you an edge over most players in PvP.Also, don't forget Uplay.  If you launch the game from steam, Uplay has to load up and sync, then the game tries to load.  Which can really bog down your system for no apparent reasons.Game performanceFor some reason your car stutters and jumps all over the place in cutscenese.  However you're fine during the gameplay itself (albeit capped at 30 to 60fps).  This has been a bug known since before release from what I've been reading, but nothing's been done to fix it.Your car handles like crap.  If you watch closely, when you're travelling at speed your car doesn't follow real world physics: it pivots on an axis instead of turning.  This is extremely apparent if you visit a highway with steady curves or a race track, you can watch as the trunk of the car slides out and the wheels don't line up to where the car is heading when you're not drifting.Speaking of wheels not lining up, visit an airport.  The aircraft (which are all scaled down and scaled up copies of each other) are just static models that slide around.  Their wheels don't spin and the nose gear doesn't turn.  Heck, they don't have any animations at all, and their engines are obvious polygons.  I haven't seen aircraft that poorly modelled since 1998.In conclusion:  Hell no.  I wasted $40 on a game where you have to grind for days on end before you're even competitive, or give Ubisoft more money.(The tiny straw that broke the camels back:  They made New York and Chicago huge and detailed, but my ENTIRE state gets a few highways and a handful of buildings?  The two towns they added and named are literally a dozen or so buildings.  And they're both tourist trap villages, they didn't add our biggest city or our capital.)EDIT:  almost forgot!  The AI cheats.  Regardless of how much more upgraded your car is, they speed up to keep up with you, and dirt roads don't affect them.  They get to fly at max speed as if they're on pavement, while you're struggling to stay on the track as you drift around corners.  Even if your Dirt Spec is levelled up far more than theirs.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												I will separate this into two categories: Single Player and Multiplayer. Seeing as both have different stories to tell, I feel it would be appropriate to split them up. Warning, there may be spoilers, but nothing that will ruin the whole story. Enjoy.Single player:The single player has a great story, as do most games made by Ubisoft. You start the story as Alex Taylor, a man and brother who gets put into prison and framed for his brothers' death, which was caused by the main antagonist, Shiv. Throughout the story, you compete and earn your rank through a sort of street gang lead by various characters by their status, (V2, V4, V6) ultimately trying to get to the top, V8, where Shiv stands. Each city you unlock, which I might add are major cities throughout the United States, (LA, New York, Miami, etc.) you gain new members to your crew, or basically guidance and emotional support to your driving and discovery of locations, races and more. Your crew becomes a valuable asset to you, both becoming good friends and especially people you can count on. Now, for the actual review part:The single player had some good moments, great scenes, and overall a great racing experience. The handling of vehicles is the best I've seen throughout all my years of racing games, and takes the cake for that. The only thing I really wish they would have done was spend more time on the ending. It seemed very rushed and very anti-climactic. This though does not change my overall feel of the game, I still love it. Multiplayer:Multiplayer can be a separate story on its own simply in the fact you can basically go anywhere, with anyone. Traveling far distances with friends or strangers can be quite a great experience, especially if you can tolerate driving for literally hours at a time in real time. To put into perspective, you can probably make it across the whole map (let's say LA to Maine) in about an hour, or close to. This is driving at full speed, at least at 330km/h (at least I was). There's plenty of places to visit, plenty of great atmospheric areas to go to. It can be very biased, but if you're not into driving for hours at a time, I wouldn't bother playing multiplayer, I'd just stick to the story. All in all, it's a great game for what it's worth, can include hundreds of hours of multiplayer time if you're into it, or if not, you can free roam around at your will (and even go offroading in a dirt spec or raid vehicle!).
